comments: There is still a great deal of work that needs to be done on work place discrimination / harassment.  Since the last survey it only seems to have become worse.  Inappropriate comments regarding a person's ethnicity, sexual orientation, and mental health unfortunately exist in many work units.

"Collaborative approach within branch or organization will lead more streamlined, quick and meaningful outcomes. Seems duplication of efforts among various branch and various ministries within BCPS. Streamlining efforts is necessary."
Permit more flexible working arrangements: four-day work weeks, working from home some days, more part-time positions for those who wish to work part-time…
...In spite of air purifiers throughout the office, I still feel that we do not work in a healthy building. Eye and respiratory problems plague us regularly.

"It is unethical and exploitative to keep bringing the same long-term auxiliaries on as employees for an indefinite amount of years, sometimes decades, without any clear path or expectation toward regular employment status.  I have seen this happen for years and it continues to be a problem in the Ministry of Forests..."

I feel the one thing that we have been challenged with is the freedom to be able to hire staff to support the increase in workloads. We want to support our staff and develop them to move forward in their career's but it is difficult (at least in my area) to hire. Each time we have a vacancy we need to appeal to fill it with justification. I understand we need to be prudent in our hiring decisions but as managers… there should be some delegation to that person to hire staff. I feel an escalated process fits when the FTE is unfunded but having to continuously put up requests for funded positions is difficult and does not help overall staff morale. It also impacts workflows and work life balance.
There should be less political influence in my organization. There should be set policy relating to the relationship between ministry staff and GCPE and work prioritization.
"We have been asking for 10  years and 4 wes surveys to tell the employer we are so underpaid and under valued and can not continue to support our families with the low pay and minimal benefits. "

Significant increases in wages. Our wages compared to similar other professions are significantly lower, which contributes to staff leaving faster than the branch can hire replacements. We are currently working with bare minimum staffing levels, which leads to staff being over-worked while feeling under-paid. This affects morale, sick time, and overall job satisfaction.

…Transition with the new government has been very challenging.  Executive has not adequately defined priorities and aligned the structure and support with appropriate staff resources.  As a result there is a sense of frustration, over-load of work and while there have been moments of recognition, my perception is they are insincere.   Lots of talk about workplace engagement at many levels yet seems to be little or slow responses to the input provided by others.

Supporting requests for improvements to public facing and internal government online systems. It is frustrating that there are so many operational barriers to seeking to improve systems that would benefit the citizens of B.C. as users and would assist B.C. Public Servants to be more effective in their roles.
"I am an auxiliary employee.  I feel there are far too many of us. There have been auxiliary positions in my unit for a while. I have seen this in many areas…"

"The province and my organization need to figure out what strategies are going to be employed with regards to First Nation rights and title and implementation of UNDRIP.  Most of our program's stress and workload is the result of unclear or unfulfilled expectations of our local FN's..."
Secure reliable funding for ongoing programs, rather than having to do business development off the side of our desks.
"Pair people up from outside of their work unit to encourage cross unit connection."

There is support for training in concept but limited time to actually go to  training...Even an active encouragement of a mentoring program to find out what occurs in different ministries, and how training could lead to different career paths, might be another way to support resiliency and engagement.  This might exist already but I think it needs to be formalized strongly to be effective.

Refresh technology and address serious facilities issues. The computer equipment available to us is dated, slow, and prone to glitches which create delays. The facility itself has significant issues which impact comfort and safety… Better equipment and facilities would allow me to be more effective in my work.
Increase salary levels across the board to remain a competitive employer.

"Improve the open office environment. You can't take a single call or make one without everyone hearing. You can't talk to people (have to find a quiet room). Space for working in some cases is very narrow/small."
More growth and opportunities for advancement within the work unit and Ministry. As well, more opportunities for job swaps/exchanges between ministries as well as public sector organizations.

A clear idea of what it is that we are trying to accomplish.   A clear concise mission statement of what it is we are trying to do, how we are going to do it and the qualitative measurement to say that we are hitting those milestones. There is too much 'ethereal ideas' passed around as hard solid things we are doing, how we are going to do it.   I have no idea how the work I do day to day fits into the 'mission statement' of my ministry.  As the mission statement is so vague that no one can really tell us what it actually means.
Allow more freedom on using new tools/equipment to do our work. Allow employees to customize their equipment requirements as they have the best knowledge of the tools/equipment to do their jobs.

"More training in mental health and addictions issues so we as workers have the skills we need to provide empathetic and client centered service to those we serve at Income Assistance. We are often the only people outside of the addiction cycle these clients see in a month and we could offer much more help with very little effort or expense on our side."

"When staff are ambitious and motivated to progress in their career, do your best to match them up with more senior staff that could pass down some of their skills and knowledge. Not doing so results in a level of apathy and discouragement which is very hard to overcome. "
Improving the onboarding experience, including a stronger focus on probation...setting clear expectations and providing new employees with the support they require to be successful in their role.

"The ministry needs to hire more employees, so offices won't be understaffed. Currently, lack of staff causes high workload (sometimes overwhelming), frequent change of work assignment, more stress at work and difficulties to balance work-life (as it directly affects vacation planning)."
"Computer speeds are slow, the network speed is so slow and can be improved."
"I would like my organization to remember it serves the public, the ministries, and Government, not the currently elected party…"

Understanding that when you change the work for one unit, it has a ripple effect for the others and so the other units need to be considered. Usually feels like one work unit is at the bottom of the pile and not as valued.

"Staffing. My work unit is understaffed and as a result, we are all having to work many extra hours in an irregular environment and it has become very taxing. I have a great Supervisor but he/she is often filling in for missing staff so he/she is unable to always be available and is not always able to keep up with Supervisory duties as a result.  Being able to deliver the best service and to work with the highest standards are very important to me."

"The people I work with are awesome and promote a positive work environment; however, space issues are a significant problem - workstations are small, background noise impacts conversations with clients, particularly when discussing information of a confidential nature...”
"The administrative workload is too large, having employees to help offload some of that work so our level can focus on other aspects would be beneficial for all."
"...Increased attention to strategic HR matters to avoid continuity gaps and unmanageable workloads.  Increased succession planning to avoid loss of corporate memory."

"Executive could spend time interacting with staff and their work so that decision makers in government are not so removed from the work 'on the ground' and to understand the impact of their decisions…"
Updates to technology need to happen in a timely manner. These laptops are heavy and outdated. We need more input and choice on the tools we use.

Greater emphasis on medium and long term goals (even some short-term ones) instead of objectives centred on political promises/platforms. Dedicate more resources in improving inter-departmental and inter-governmental communications, creating more innovative and collaborative policy-making.
Training for the new Employee needs to be improved; struggling with learning. First few months very hard to find out things. Some training sessions would be appreciative.

"The Technology we have to use in our workplace is basically obsolete.   I understand budgets, but skimping on the quality of our technology (Multi Function Devices etc) only create downtime due to service and repairs of the substandard equipment. Sure it looks cheap on the books, but the overall cost to the ministry, as a result of 'down time' makes these cheap technology decisions cost more in the long run, and severely impact efficiency. "
"It would be nice if there was more opportunities to enter into a career path set of jobs (meaning start at an 18 and clearly see a way to advance through  21s, 24s,  27s, and 30s)"
My organization needs to include quality in the analysis of tools, processes and decisions. At the moment cost is the sole defining factor and is leading to substandard work.
"The organization needs to determine what its role is. There is little leadership on strategic direction."

"Stop cutting the office cleaning budgets!  The quality of cleanliness throughout the District and Regional offices I have visited has dropped noticeably.  Office spaces, common areas and washrooms are definitely not as clean as they should be!  The standard of clean has been reduced creating an environment for colds and the flu, germs to flourish.  This translates to lost time as a result."
"The office space is just not functional or inspiring lay-out wise. It is noisy and too crowded. The desk space and ergonomics of the chairs are not safe or conducive to a healthy work environment…"
"Increase pay so that it is competitive with industry and the private sector."

Stabilize software and web applications.  Stop changing the user interface of work-place tools such as Employee Self Service, Time On Line, the Intranet and Ministry web format and appearance. Fix poorly designed software, especially IPS, which prevents administration of the Ministry's business due to its [many] flaws.

The one thing that our organization should focus on to improve the work environment would be to focus on hiring more staff. The workers are being drained with their high and complex caseloads. I have noted that most MCFD workers are passionate and driven workers. However, they are limited in their work due to high caseloads. In order to minimize the stress the organization should make more attempts to hire new staff within higher volume service delivery areas...

"Since we are all working in very closer quarters, some groups tend to be noisier than others which can be very distracting when trying to focus.  Provide tools (i.e. noise cancelling headphones) to help alleviate tensions that build when one group likes to discuss everything in the open versus a group that tends to keep their heads down and work quietly."
Understanding from the Executive around work/life balance - hire more staff perhaps so that work in evenings and weekends is less frequent, particularly when not compensated for it.

Timely, open communications are required. Even an email saying we don't have the all the answers but this is what we're working towards to give people an idea of what is coming so there are no unpleasant surprises.

Executive team demonstrates great leadership and management style, cares about their people, shows intention and commitment to change workplace culture. However, this does not translate through middle management. Old fashioned management style is out of touch in this new era. Managing and leading as a coach is needed, instead of using authority to control. Open conversations and a safe environment to understand staff's needs and to demonstrate they care about staff's long term career.
"I work in the field, my environment is unpredictable and potentially dangerous. Personal Safety training would be beneficial."
"Hire more appropriate employees for the work. Many people are coming from a different educational background than what is needed for the work."

"Pay is the biggest problem for the job we do. We are losing staff at an alarming late to police agencies and federal organizations. If the pay and benefits were competitive with federal organizations, I am confident we would be able to retain staff and improve morale of staff."
Create more senior [classification] positions within the branch. My job has limited career advancement prospects.

The hiring process takes way too long to fill and often causes unnecessary stress to other employees who have to do more with less.  It would be better if the hiring process was started prior to incumbent leaving so that the new person starts within a week of the position being vacant.
"Skill development for staff is extremely important along with coaching in career development."
"Transparency seems to have evaporated."
Give us up-to-date equipment and software (not 2010 versions in 2018).

…99.9% of communication from the Ministry has no bearing or consequences for [my work unit]. [My work unit] has not been mentioned in any meaningful way in any communication. Our work has never once been recognized.
Job classifications and pay!  The workloads and responsibilities for included administrative positions are grossly inequitable.

I make the same comment every time I complete this survey.  I find that the equipment we are provided with to do the job (e.g. computers, photocopiers, printers) are constantly breaking down.  The job is difficult to do when the equipment is frequently breaking down or not working.  The computer system is the biggest concern for me.

The government needs to provide proper computer and office equipment, such as photocopiers, to Crown offices, so that the people in those offices can carry out their duties. This includes sufficient scanners to comply with electronic file requirements, the lack of which is a serious impediment. The government does not provide this equipment, thereby incurring both labour costs and lower productivity, to the detriment of the people we serve. It is penny wise and pound foolish to do this. Private sector law firms sometimes, in my experience, make the same mistake, but I have never seen the same level of indifference to the day to day need for lawyers and staff to have the tools required for the job at their disposal, outside of government.

Allow for a graduated/gradual entry into retirement rather than an all or nothing approach.  This would allow employees to ease into retirement and allow the employer to better engage into succession planning and ease the effect of baby boomer retirement.

Salary. Wages have been steadily declining against the cost of living. Even though I have received promotions have had to cut back in my personal life because my spending power has been steadily diminishing over my career.

Update printers and computers - we are left with out of date equipment that affects our day to day work.  Printers are slow, computers are slow.  We get more work, but he equipment we have been provided is horrible.   Work spaces consist of old furniture, put together willy nilly.
Hire or promote appropriate people instead of by favouritism, seems to be done by who you know not what you know

Fairness in the hiring process.  Competency interviews are very subjective to the people who are on the hiring panel.  I do not believe that the person who is leaving the position or the immediate supervisor should be on the panel.  I also believe that if there are current employees applying for the job, the interview panel should consist of no one who works in that current location.  Regardless of how competency interviews are slated to be fair, I do not believe that a supervisor/manager who has a pre-conception of an employee can avoid that opinion from coloring their views on how the employee did in the interview.

Deal with bullying, disrespect and incompetence.  The behaviour of one person in a position of influence has created a toxic environment resulting in many staff looking to leave, particularly experienced staff.  For the sake of the branch, we can't afford to let this continue.

Succession planning and management. While some good work has been started, I have not seen evidence that anyone is seriously going to fill vacancies using this work, especially at the Executive level. Nor have I seen evidence that supplemental training or supports will be provided to those who wish to move up in their career. We are having good conversations...now we need to put our money where our mouth is as well as show how this work is actually being used.

Improve opportunities for career development/advancement, for example, through in-house training, supporting applications for Pacific Leaders scholarships, approving requests for learning centre courses, providing in-house mentorship opportunities, etc. Perhaps creating another level for admin support so that [upper level admin staff] have an opportunity for advancement within the office but can remain working for this unit in a more responsible role. Our office is important to the province and it would be appreciated if we were given opportunities to help the public in more meaningful ways and could do so if positions with more responsibility were an option.

Improve our physical wok environment. We are working on desks from 1970s. Carpets haven't been changed (let alone washed) in decades. Building not wired or set up for todays tech. Building grounds are sketchy and can also be challenging in inclement weather. Building from 1970s and in desperate need of upgrading for the staff to work effectively! Public can't even access half the space via wheelchair because of this. Elevators break down all the time too.

Find proper physical space to accommodate the needs of all branch employees.  Do not force open-concept design on us.  For most of us it would severely inhibit our ability to do our work, since we need quiet for thinking and privacy for confidential information and conversations.

I would like the negative employees in my work group to be dealt with prompt action. It only takes one employee to destroy morale in our office. I am tired of how a few poison employees can break morale, and don't like coming to work.
The work load, stress and being under staffed every day for years leaves us exhausted with a feeling of hopelessness.  There is no balance of work and personal life.

I would like to see improvements in the personal work space.  Staff who wish to enhance their physical comfort should be able to.  An option to have a standing desk or a new and modern phone headset should be available to employees.  This would include a new, upgraded and more comfortable chair if necessary.

Giving government employees pay raises would make the cost of living in Vancouver and Victoria easier places to live.  Every year that goes by the government salaries are not keeping pace with the cost of living.  On a global provincial scale the BC government contributes to a huge part of the working population. Alberta provincial government salaries are far higher than BC provincial government salaries and their cost of living is lower.

Hire people who have the skills required to be a good supervisor or people manager even if they don't have extensive experience. To do this, hiring managers should do more testing for organizational fitness in competitions. Please stop hiring bad managers who may have many years of experience but are simply bad people managers. Recognize and support high functioning, strong performers regardless of what they work on. People tend to get recognition and promotions based on how visible their work is. If it's a high profile project, they are recognized, even if their work is average or below average. If it's not a high profile project or file, they do not get recognized even if they are high performers.

Our office and equipment is very run down. Desks are old and not well designed. Chairs are old, broken and dirty. It is embarrassing to have visitors in a board room where a sign has been on the credenza that it is broken for several years and it is not replaced or fixed. Most of the chairs are broken. Computers are slow and are not maintained and updated regularly enough.

"Our work unit is very short staffed. It's impossible to complete my duties with existing staff levels - this can make work very stressful. Although I enjoy my work, I'm doing the job of more than one and it's frustrating."

There is one major problem within my work unit. We are paid very poorly. we are losing valuable, experienced, hard working people to other high paying agencies. We are in dire need of a raise. this will alleviate most of our issues and attract more people to apply for our service.

Be proactive in providing replacement staff when our coworkers are off on secondment or leave or retire.  The turn around is too long and the stress placed on the current staff is too great for too long.
new hired management being more knowledgeable in various aspects of the job requirements

"This comment is directed more at the branch/work unit level. The workload is excessive and unmanageable and has been for [several years]. Some staff are underutilized while others are continually being buried by the high volume of day-to-day work, government/ministry initiatives and branch projects currently in progress. There is no time available to properly plan/prioritize work, update procedure manuals, train staff properly, or take a few extra minutes to think about what it is you are trying to accomplish. Because of this, there is higher incidence of errors, backtracking, stress/frustration. I, personally, want to be proactive in my approach to prioritizing, rather than 'reacting', which is basically the normal culture in my unit."

Salary alignment amongst lawyers, paralegals and support staff needs to be fair.  Lawyers in our branch get continuous and significant increases in their salaries regardless of whether they over achieve or under achieve.  However, individuals in supporting roles do not and  remain under paid with stagnant wages.  It does not appear that our branch or Executive is passionate enough about it. In fact, the message that appears to be sent out is that there is nothing we can do, it's up to the PSA and the PSA does not agree that work skills of those that play a supporting role in a busy litigation branch are any different than those of other clerical staff in the public sector.  This is not true and our branch needs to make that distinction.

Hope we have a better benefit package within BC Public Service. It's been downgraded over the past years.  Our salaries are not catching up with the inflation/basic standard living expenses(Victoria). The minimum wage will be going up 34% over 5 years period, but our wages going up 1%/year roughly. Hope this can be considered as well.

Loosen the purse strings or advocate for an adequate budget to provide us the space, furniture and tools we need to do our jobs efficiently and without long-term injury. Doing so will have the added bonus of boosting morale since it will recognize that we all deserve well-lit, quiet office space; modern, fully functioning, mould-free furniture; and up-to-date technology that we can work with rather than work around.
Retention!!! We are losing quality employees due to a lack of fair pay. Retention issues lead to so many of the other issues we are having within this organization.

Sheriffs deserve competitive wages aligning with other law enforcement agencies. Sheriff wage should reflect the daily dangers of dealing with violent prisoners and having to make split second emergency decisions utilizing use of force tools.
A pay increase is an absolute must. I'm embarrassed when people ask me about my pay. I can't believe I live paycheque to paycheque as a dedicated law enforcement officer
The current pay grid does not reflect the cost of living in British Columbia.  I am actively looking at private sector jobs that pay twice as much for my skill set and level of education.

Demote, discipline and/or fire bullies.  Ineffective dealing with bullying, revictimizing the vulnerable and causing them to feel punished for coming forward.  Too much sweeping under the rug and allowing bullies to flourish and continue to act the way that they do, even with clear evidence of their deplorable behaviour.

Consider ergonomic impacts of office furniture design and permit accommodations as a preventative measure, rather than in response to problems. There is a false economy in a requirement to have a medically documented problem before taking steps to improve ergonomics, because of lost productivity in later dealing with the problem that could have been prevented.
Double standards are not healthy in any organization, group or office.

We need more staff in many departments within court services. It's unfair to have the heavy workloads with time constraints in several departments resulting in hours of overtime and ending up with overwhelmed, exhausted staff. We need the help and we need to hire more people so that the work can be divided fairly. If this could happen I believe it would have such a positive impact on team environments and morale.

"Culture needs to change at management level for morale to improve. Currently an environment of favouritism, nepotism, and cronyism prevails within our organization at management level. Overall I feel that management engages in the buddy system far too often with a detrimental effect on frontline morale. Looking after their friends seems of more importance than betterment of the organization. Little to no advocacy for frontline staff from senior supervisors or management with regards to ongoing needs/safety of staff.. This organization soon needs a complete rebuild."

I know no one likes spending money on infrastructure, but honestly the computer network issues, insanely slow printer and the embarrassing state of my office environment are my biggest daily aggravations and drains on time I could spend doing my job much more effectively.

Morale here is continuing to decline to abysmal levels. Leadership seems totally disconnected with the discontent, and oblivious to the fact that almost every person in here is checking postings daily….
… In terms of office culture, there's a definite culture of favouritism. Opportunities and praise are only given to a select group and the hard work of others is often ignored.

"We do not have adequate manpower and training for support staff. [One of my staff members] is on the edge of complete burnout because she is forced to do the jobs of two people. We need to hire more support staff and better train the ones we have."

"There is not enough staff or support (if there are shortages in staff). However, this is said each and every time this survey comes out, which means there is not enough follow-up from the organization."

I would like to see employees held accountable for the work they are not doing. It seems like there is never any disciplinary action taken and employees who severely underperform are permitted to keep their positions. It makes it difficult to strive to excel in my role when others that skate by receive the same recognition and opportunities.

I would like us to stop using the competency questions style of interview.  I find that with more than half the people who won the positions they only know how to answer the question to get the position but do not in reality perform in that position well.  We depend too munch on how the candidates answer the question, NOT how they actually perform in past jobs or their actual attributes.  It makes it very disheartening.

Appropriate staffing levels in the office is the number one problem where I work. Constantly being understaffed and having to pull people here and there to fill holes is stressful and exhausting to everyone in the office. Hiring more staff would be beneficial

More meaningful oversight for supervisors is needed.  The supervision my team receives is inadequate and while there are initiatives underway to improve leadership in the branch through training and workshops there doesn't seem to be much in the way of oversight for supervision.  This leaves my work unit in a place we often don't have the information that we need to do our jobs and when we ask questions we are unable to get meaningful responses.  Our feedback also stops at supervisor and our ideas/suggestions are not carried forward and acted on.  With better supervision my team would be aware of what is happening in the branch and would be able to provide input and feedback on decisions that are being made.

"Take HR complaints seriously instead of telling us to [look the other way] when dealing with coworkers who are negatively impacting my ability to work. There must be consequences for unacceptable behaviour. It almost seems impossible to be let go after you've been here for years, no matter how atrocious your work or attitude is. This is not inspiring."
Provide uninterrupted opportunities for training and participating in learning sessions.

Supervisors should have HR experience. The high turnover in the office is not only due to the large workload but also that the management team doesn't know how to deal with HR issues in an effective manner.

Overall, although I enjoy my colleagues, I find they tend towards negativity in conversation with one another/talking to oneself, or in their actions/behavior. It has an unmistakeable ripple effect on the rest of the office that can have a prolonged impression; making it a challenge to promote a healthy work atmosphere and maintain job satisfaction. It is evident in speech and behavior patterns - cuss words mumbled under the breath but still audible, raised voices & speaking over one another are commonplace…

I think that opportunities are limited to a selected few and often forward learning is limiting depending on the position that is held.  I think one should be able to learn new things that are of interest to them and not offered based on what management decides
"…There's some movement towards recognizing burnout and mental health, but more could be done."

"Supervisory roles…should have the opportunity to take courses to strengthen their leadership and supervising skills, as well as proper conduct in an office setting, conflict resolution and communication skills."

I find that while our managerial staff is excellent and very responsive to concerns, our supervisors are not always the same. There has been a high turnover in supervisors in our branch and they lack consistency, confidence and empathy with the staff on personal levels. The attitude is very 'us vs. them' and doesn't always lead to a positive, happy environment.

Have supervisors and senior employees provide more detailed oversight of work projects and more substantive feedback on the quality of work product for people on their teams. It is sometimes difficult for more junior members of the public service to gauge their strengths, weaknesses, and quality of overall performance without the opportunity to receive detailed feedback on their work product.

Work life balance - There is such a high volume of workload that we can't keep up to the demand. Our Executive communicate that they don't expect us to be working evenings and weekends but they also still expect the work to get completed so there is a disconnect. Since new government has come in, the pace and volume of work is 2-3 times higher than before and no resources have been added. This is not sustainable. I would like to see our organization focus on a better work life balance and implementing the needed resources.
"More effective leadership from group supervisor and far less (zero) tolerance for sub-par work performance (bordering on negligence in some instances)…"
Currently there is no room for advancement or opportunity to move forward. The current terms of reference do not allow peers to gain the experience needed to compete for more senior positions.
I would like the BC Public Service to hire an immediate manager and a supervising manager that has the proper education and experience to properly handle the day to day operation of my work unit.

The reduction of nepotism. It is quite prevalent that there are no strict rules around nepotism and people are favored through hiring, promotions, opportunities etc. Management becomes biased and cannot separate their feelings/biased. Also, we see family get hired and promoted quite a bit. Ontario has strict nepotism policies and would be good to look at.

My direct supervisor is not a good trainer and it falls on the rest of us to train new staff, while that puts us behind our own work.  Also my direct supervisor lets the daily stress get to them and snaps at the staff often.  This supervisor is in a job above their current skills.
A better understanding of how to achieve promotions within my organization, for example, courses or training that would give you a better opportunity for promotion or new job within the organization.
Better training. Dealing with people's documents and lives is a very important responsibility and the training and support from supervisors needs to be better.

I would have liked a lengthier training period for the job, like a full week or two with the previous incumbent/a training supervisor. I feel this would have helped me grasp a wider variety of tasks within the job, and provided more of an opportunity to learn with supervision.

Pay/salary/wages.   The main issue that has affected the overall retention of valid and talented staff staying within this organization has been the wage gap compared to other law-enforcement. Until this issue is rectified, the B.C Sheriffs will continue to suffer in attrition of its members.
Upward momentum programs for lower level positions. A system that provides clear direction married with opportunity to obtain higher level training and positions.

The financial struggles that admin workers suffer due to the progressively lower and lower wages versus cost of living in BC is having a negative and unhealthy effect in the workplace.  The employees are always in a state of worry and apprehension as to how to pay just the basics i.e. rent, food, transit, childcare etc.  We cannot continue to work in public service at these wages when the private sector is offering at least twice the amount (combined wages and benefits) for the same skills. For this reason I could not (and do not) recommend the BC Government as an employer at this time
Supervisors who do not meet the requirements of their job descriptions and / or follow the government work values should be retrained or removed.

Our office requires additional staff. Currently, every employee is working at what should be considered beyond maximum workload. There are not enough resources to assist the public with phone calls, walk-ins, unexpected complications, and several other similar situations. The environment of the workplace is focused on staying afloat, and is unable to open up to the needs of the public outside of the pre-determined workload. I feel that with additional staffing we would benefit in that we would be able to provide better service to the public and increase efficiency overall as there would be more opportunities to assist people on a daily basis that will result in less complications in the future.
Establishing ongoing exec level meetings (Director and above) within the [division] would improve high to low level information flow and improve overall staff confidence in Executive.

Physical space of the office - lack of proper ventilation in the office - especially this winter the office has been very hot and causing lots of sickness and headaches. With so many people in the office, steps should be taken to remedy to this problem. This also affects how we perform at work.
More opportunities for promotion from within, and developing the competencies needed to be qualified for promotions.

Hire supervisors with better supervisory skills OR train them to be more effective, and ask their direct reports for feedback. I've had way too many supervisors over the past 5 years... A few good, a few really bad.
Modernize the work space/experience to make it more flexible and mobile; 8:30-4:30 in a cubicle is not so inspiring.
There needs to be better communication channels between the senior people (who decide strategic direction) and the operations staff (who implement the strategies).
More frequent updates from Ministry Senior Executive - DM, ADM level.
…Executive need to get out of the office, meetings, etc., and engage with their staff. They have the knowledge and small conversations can share a lot of information.
A clear ministry/division-focused onboarding program.
Making sure staff are accountable for their work and deadlines, work attendance.
…Several staff 'work from home' 4 days a week. Others are not allowed to. Why is that? Some managers are not allowed to while Union staff are.

With such a big change-over of priorities and values in government in the past year, it has been somewhat confusing to be a new employee for my organization. Some of the changes in organizational structure don't seem to make sense for our line of work. I would like my organization to focus on being a little clearer about the strategy that informs these changes. The strategy seems a bit opaque - maybe almost as if we don't really know what we're doing.
Less stressful deadlines and more cross-training of employees so that we can better provide assistance and back up to each other when needed…
Since there is a fairly high turnover in clerical positions, make sure there are very good training plans in place so they can become knowledgeable quickly.
Provide flexibility to staff and you will be amazed what you get back in return. Managing staff like children results in childlike staff.

We have not yet found our strategic vision post-election to integrate all of the various JTT pieces into a coherent, relevant, timely plan. We need an economic growth strategy that ties us all together…
…Need to better support middle management to grow as leaders and get feedback.
Create lots of opportunities to do TAs within other units in the organization. This will increase employee knowledge and experience and facilitate succession planning.

I understand the cost savings behind moving to a leading workplace strategy open work environment but having a dedicated / regular work spot is much more efficient and allows me to work more effectively. Having to set-up my computer and pack everything up into a locker at the end of the day is really inefficient.
Lead with empathy, and uphold values espoused by the PSA. Work better to create a positive environment rather than authoritative management styles…
More support and supervisory training for those who lead staff.

Quite a bit of traffic/noise in my work area. Would be nice if there were reminders of a quiet zone. I am also dependent on wireless internet at my work station, which greatly decreases my productivity as it is down several times throughout the day, every day. I would suggest either a wired solution, or the possibility of working at home as my work does not require me to be client facing, and everything could be done remotely.
The ability to work from home/to be a part of tele-work would be great!
…Directors need to be more receptive to change to improve the program.

Some work units have the latest laptop/tablets/ while others are still using old/outdated technology. Please provide fair and equal access to tools. If one unit gets an upgrade, please provide to all units.

The Ministry needs to focus on developing ways to bring input and skillsets from the various groups together on projects in order to feel like we are one ministry rather than many groups working separately.

I acknowledge that we've undergone a ministry change but the fact that we've gone [time period] with no IT support for our projects has been very challenging. As of this date, we still do not know who manages the server for our site, or who to contact for changes. A change to this would greatly improve my ability to complete some of the work.
Stronger cohesion- I have no idea what it would look like to have everyone in our ministry put in a room together.
Better office equipment such as a standing desk.
Ensuring staff at all levels are included in meetings and information sharing.
More engagement / communication across business units/branches (i.e.. monthly joint meetings, etc.).

Integration and cross-pollination between related initiatives. Work is too often completed in silos when different branches would work more effectively if we were kept aware of other initiatives that may impact our work and stakeholders.
Consider allowing all staff members to work flexible work schedules, working from home.
Greater clarity on processes to secure funding for new initiatives would be helpful.

I believe the cost-recovery status of my unit has created fewer opportunities for growth and change within my unit and has negatively changed the framework of our work. There is less flexibility to try different approaches to our work, and reduced the focus on due diligence and program integrity. There is a greater focus on numbers in order to reach financial targets and mixed messaging from upper management in terms of our role and responsibility in the cost-recovery model. I would like there to be a change which includes a greater emphasis put towards program integrity in the work unit.
Computer speed and availability of second monitors at workstations for mobile workers.
…Communication! Whether it be telling people about [business updates], or best practices, or high level issues, there needs to be a better way to ensure the messaging goes out.
…Have upward feedback mechanism (especially for Executive positions/promotions to hold exec. accountable for staff engagement)…

We need clearer direction from an Executive level on [work unit’s] role, what we are trying to achieve and how we are structured and resourced to deliver that. I feel like we are always two steps behind what we are being asked to deliver in terms of having the time/people/skillsets to do what is desired. While it may have been seen as necessary to [make organizational changes], there should have been a much better thought out transition plan. Ultimately the stress of figuring that out fell to the 'workers' who are already pushed to the max.
More opportunities for career development would be beneficial and more discussion around career progression would be appreciated.
More satellite offices for Westshore commuters…

Consider LWS impact more carefully. Purported benefits of LWS are improved collaboration and flexibility but plans show less meeting rooms, no training room, and many more people packed on each floor…

More direction and consistency with the upcoming move to LWS. One one hand, the overall movement and initiatives supports flexible and mobile options for work and on the other, the sense is that we will still be expected to come into work, even though space and the building will not be able to support everyone coming in.

There is still an inadequate amount of human resources for a very busy ministry and in particular an extremely busy division.  Staff are feeling burned out. Even having 1 or 2 additional staff per unit/branch at the right levels would make a huge difference in distributing workload and also ensure good succession planning
"… Executive can sometimes help by being attuned to staff workloads and stress levels and pushing back on unreasonable requests, e.g., from the Minister's office or central agencies."

Unclear if the organization has a vision or similar beyond that identified in the Ministry Service Plan.  If it does, maybe it would be a worthwhile exercise to communicate it and/or review and update it as needed.  (If it has been some time since it was developed)
I enjoy working for the branch, but given the opportunity I would like to work closer to home.

Looking forward to LWS being completed for those who will be partaking in this initiative. However for those of us who may not be working from home it would be my preference to still have my own office instead of being in an open area floor plan.
Would like more Ministry Wide opportunities to connect, such as forums that we used to have.

Allow opportunities for staff to gain experience working with senior management, ie. participate in Executive briefings/committees, where appropriate to support succession planning.  This could also improve the flow of information between Executive and staff.
Greater support for active transportation, e.g. include change/locker rooms in all buildings. LWS renovations is the opportunity to add facilities that encourage healthy living choices.
Streamlining internal processes.

"Improved transparency and communication from Executive to staff. There has been a lot of transition in our ministry, and work unit. Improved messaging would help build confidence in staff that they are charting a planned course."
I know Deputy Ministers are very busy; I'd like more regular DM level communication. In person is excellent, but regular email updates are also very helpful to provide context to our work.
Better change management strategy and implementation.
Reduce levels of approval as it creates inefficiency and appears as a lack of trust reducing motivation and individual accountability in the lower ranks.

Provide employees with more flexibility to achieve work/life balance, e.g. allow employees to work from home on a regular basis if performance is satisfactory and job requirements allow working from home.

Clear articulation of the long term vision of the organization and how that vision will be achieved and maintained over time and through periods of change/challenge.  Sharing a pathway to a vision provides confidence and stability in uncertain environments.
Get the temperature in the building regulated better
More information, direction and expectations needs to be provided from the top down.
Provide the staff with new, powerful and faster and lighter laptops. Existing computers are 5  years old and working with them is really frustrating.

Improved communication about the work being undertaken across branches within the division. As a relatively new employee to this division, it has been difficult to navigate the landscape in terms of who does what and where the overlaps/opportunities for collaboration are/may be.
"Be more diligent about filling vacancies and also create more dynamic positions and then fill those positions…"

Give us more time to prepare for changes and review the changes. Although we are told of changes (e.g., to legislation to policies), it is important to have time to review and digest the information. I would like time to review/respond to emails, upkeep of my mailbox; review newsletters, etc.
Proper work space that works for everyone (size, sound etc)
"Additional FTEs for program areas - over the past three years Executive offices continue to grow while program areas are left under resourced…"

…LWS workplaces should be re-commissioned every 3 years. We started with 50 people on this floor. Now we have 80. Plants, collaboration tables, sitting areas have been removed in favour of cramming in lockers and more cattle car desks. It seems no one is managing the workspace and relying on the 'flexibility' of the concept.

Provide adequate coverage, which probably means hiring more people, so that employees know their work can be covered if they are sick or away on vacation. It's hard to leave work behind and take a break when you feel the people/business/projects fall behind or don't have help while you are away. Also, returning to a huge volume of work feels like being punished for having time off.
"Better technology: updated laptops, better/more stable office Wi-Fi connection."
Move away from the sector support model (aka supporting four ministries).

Given existing responsibilities and programs, plus many emerging priorities, and an ever-more complex policy environment, the ministry should be able to significantly increase the number of staff (including policy analysts and admin support) so that we can deal with existing high workloads, work more proactively (and less reactively), and seize opportunities.
A bit better organization at the DMO level, to minimize rework and last minute requests that didn't need to be last minute.
Avoid short-term solutions that conflict with long-term goals. Keep focus on service to British Columbians.
To provide more learning opportunities or cross training to advance and gain more knowledge/skills to be able to move up the ladder in government.
"More opportunities for professional development within the branch (i.e. mentoring, support, developmental TA's)..."

"Opportunities for growth/promotion are limited. I am very happy in my sector and would like to remain, however, if I need to grow (Career wise) I am forced to explore opportunities outside my sector…"
Create more mentorship, training and growth opportunities for internal staff members. Especially staff members that are interested in changing career streams within the Public Service.
Remove florescent lighting for something better for the eyes, and ensure every employee has exposure to natural lighting from their workstation.
More understanding about how the municipal affairs side of the Ministry and the housing side of the Ministry relate together and how they can support each other.
Promote within the organization - make it easier for people already in the public service to advance before out sourcing jobs

The computer equipment is adequate but it takes a long time to get software/hardware problems resolved. I have been unable to perform my job on a number of occasions due to slow response for software resolutions.
"I feel quite overwhelmed with the amount of work I have at the moment and the very tight timelines; I don't think it is sustainable."

I would like my organization to set a clear vision for the future. Communicate the goals for the organization and the steps we will be taking to reach our goals. The organization needs to celebrate the milestones reached and communicate to staff those areas where further improvement is required. I enjoy the work I do but I would be more engaged if my organization made it clear how my work is helping to meet the overall goals of the organization.
"The work environment in my office is badly in need of a facelift. The carpets need to be replaced, a fresh coat of paint would help as well and have the blinds cleaned!"
Refresh the Ministry Vision and Mission to better align with our mandate/direction.
"Move to a building that doesn't have HVAC issues."
"Offices instead of cubicles..."
"Increase staffing to accommodate demand for service."
"One thing I would like the organization to work on is work load, work load, work load."
"Staffing levels/workload.  We are currently under-staffed and the effects are being felt across the organization."

"Increase to our wages. We did not receive the same increase as union employees nor the substantial raise that Executive were given.  We do comparable work as WCB staff but do not get paid as well as they are paid for overtime…"

"We need to embrace technology far more than we do. To address the challenges of an increased workload, attrition and increased scrutiny on the work we do, we need to become a much more modern public service."
Better workplace tools and technology.

Positions within a Ministry should be offered to current employees within that Ministry based on past job performance within the Ministry. Employees who know the job, are competent and are already trained should be offered promotions without having to go through lengthy and time consuming hiring panels and 'role plays' to demonstrate that they are capable of performing a job they already do… Rewarding those who perform well with higher responsibilities encourages people to perform their best.
"Actively engage employees in career and development plans."
"The furniture in our offices could use an update/refresh."
…I suggest reviewing job descriptions so that there is less overlap, so people aren't spread so thin and so people can specialize…
I would like focus to return to external stakeholders needs and wants instead of changes to satisfy the internal wants.
"Career development, promotion from within"
"An office space with fully functioning heat and air conditioning controls accessible and modifiable in the office."
"A 10% salary increase. Same Pay Grade for everyone doing same work…"
"More support around preventative measures we can take to ensure occupational health and safety (e.g. ergonomics)."

"Allocate more resources to staffing, by filling existing vacancies and where applicable creating new positions.  This will improve work performance outcomes and provide more time for both personal and organizational growth and development."
Increasing the cap on our pay grade so that we may be incentivized to surpass our performance standards.

"Our work is highly specialized and valued and has significant impacts on BC Employers. There is significant financial value  and responsibility attached to the work we do for employers and we make complex decisions and manage complex case loads on a daily basis. Our staff are highly educated and trained and receive glowing feedback from our clients. We are not adequately compensated for the work we do , we are at the top of the pay scale in our band with no hope of raises. The pay is not competitive with comparable jobs and the flat structure does not allow promotions . I think you will find it hard to attract, motivate and maintain talent if no action is taken to recognize the expertise and value of staff and provide competitive wages."
"More opportunities for professional growth within the organization."

Recognition that the Ministry is staffed by competent, dedicated, professional public servants… While transition to new a government is inherently challenging, and transition within brand new Ministries is particularly tough - the treatment of staff within this specific Ministry has been - in my opinion- disrespectful. Following the recent release of the WES survey, there has been signs of improvement. Am hoping there will be some sustained momentum towards a more respectful environment…
More frequent and timely communication from Executive to staff on the future of the ministry within this government.
…More approvals to hire staff when money is available, should be a priority but it doesn't seem that approvals are granted that often. It is having an impact on existing staff.
Executive to report out on status and/or outcome of decision notes, and provide a summary of planned actions arising from briefing or issues notes.

Two-way communication. Currently, it is very much a top-down communication/direction approach that does not allow for informing or briefing Executive or building in their feedback. Decisions seem to be made in silos often without the materials staff have prepared and also without the opportunity for the discussion necessary to bring forward considerations, implications, historical knowledge, etc.
Improved organizational efficiency to better demonstrate to staff that their time and effort is valued.
More staff resources or a review of our strategic priorities to make the workload more manageable.
More regular interaction between Executive and included staff.

Encourage management to include junior staff in brainstorming and encourage their input because they are quite often the most knowledgeable because they are hands-on. Try to distribute tasks based on skills and interest as often as possible. People are much more engaged if they work on projects they are interested in. They are also more likely to want to stay in that division.

…My suggestion are: 1. Hire more staff. 2. Manage assignments more effectively from DMO/ADMO - decrease the 'rushes' and allot a reasonable turnaround time for work to be produced. This will also lend more credibility to the assignments that are designated as a 'rush'.

The physical environment and personal space in which I do my work is very important to me. From time to time Executive members in my organization float the idea of ‘open concept’ offices, with no cubicles or dedicated space for employees. I simply could not work in such an environment. My job requires quiet and a certain amount of physical isolation in which to read and think. Yet working from home is not an option for me either, as I need access to physical files and documents stored here.  Please don't take away the walls! We work fine, and probably better, with them than without them.
Have the Deputy Minister walk through the building more often and connect with us.
Recognize that long term employees carry a level of knowledge that is important and make sure they feel valued for their contributions.

Providing managers and supervisors with the permission (time, support and recognition) to focus on the HR components of their jobs. While I often hear it said that 'people are our greatest asset', too often our collective behaviours do not reflect the same.
…Lack of understanding of what it takes to get it done. Need more staff to support workload. Staff are stressed & burning out. Take care of staff.

The organization/PSA needs a better way to deal with or move difficult employees that have demonstrated disrespectful and extremely bad behavior in order to maintain a positive culture within the work environment.

For the past few years, it has been mostly employees who participated in ministry social and PECSF activities and auctions.  Senior Executives rarely participate or bid for anything.  They rarely get involved and yet want employees to engage and make the workplace better.   It is like the rest of the workplace environment, they don't practice what they preach.  They should model engaging actions and behaviour.  Please get to know staff, everyone from the mail clerk, student aid appeals officer, director and so on...they only mingle and interact amongst their friends or close knit group of colleagues.  Last DM was like that and our new one is similar, it seems.
Trust... Staff need to be trusted to make decisions, given the ability to make decisions without a lot of red tape. We have a lot of good, smart, capable people in our unit.
Address high volume and pace of workload.

Being clear about the distinction between leadership and management; leaders don't always have management roles...and managers are often not leaders.  Compulsory leadership assessments and professional development would go a long way, taking bolder more decisive steps when managers can't lead, and listen when your staff tries to talk to you.  Understand that for every 1 person that speaks up, there are another 10 who silently feel the same way…
Executive leadership - there needs to be a renewed and genuine focus on leading the troops.
The work unit's leadership group needs to be more open and transparent.  They need more supervisory training.  We feel lots of information is not provided to us in speedy fashion.

Upgrade some of the older computers, which appear on the brink of destruction when more than one tab is open in a web browser. My computer is fine, but I've seen what some others have to use and it's frankly embarrassing.
Ensure clear roles/responsibilities and then hold people accountable to the identified role/responsibilities.
Organization needs to implement the ‘culture we need as identified on page 13 of the 2016 Corporate HR Plan.

...A system should be in place to rate management by staff - not only a system to rate staff.  Otherwise, there is little incentive for management to improve & hence limited improvements to the overall working of gov't...

Address workload and stress in a systematic manner.  We have significantly reduced the size of the public service over the last 16 years and are continually expected to do more with less.  We produce results because we take pride in our work, however it is exhausting and taking a toll on staff well-being (physical and mental).  STIIP should not be the measure of whether we need more people resources...

…Must start hiring managers and directors from outside of AEST. It feels at AEST that genuine policy advice is something that is not encouraged here, which cannot be the case from senior management's perspective. I believe this is a product of several years of top down policy development; however, middle management has institutionalized this approach, preventing analysts and senior analysts from delving deeper into issues we should be experts on. Information from middle management is also always on a 'need to know' basis. I am completely unaware of anything that goes on beyond the files I work on... and even that information is very selectively chosen.
Communicate strategic priorities clearly.
Value staff expertise, effort, and advice in decision making.

There is an opportunity for more frequent updates and discussion of Executive priorities communicated to all staff. Quarterly town halls are simply not an adequate method to breakdown siloes between work units/branches/divisions. In my experience, monthly Live Meetings/Lync video meetings with the whole organization are an effective method to share regular updates from Executive to all staff, as well as providing an opportunity for work units across the ministry to present their work. While not every meeting needs to [be] loaded with information, it's a regular check-in that connects staff and brings the organization together.  For this to be effective there needs to be a commitment from Executive and staff will then make them a priority too.
…Staff have the sense that their Executive pay lip service to caring about them, when at the end of the day they just want the job done (sometimes at any expense)…

Not all areas here have good management and they have managers/Executives who should be held accountable for their poor treatment of employees (past and present experiences expressed by co-workers) nothing is done even though there are many complaints against certain management…
…Opportunities to engage in social events - within the division, and cross-divisional, to improve morale and connect on a personal level with colleagues…
Laptops should be mandatory for all employees, especially those with reports to's.  Not being able to take my computer into any meetings or performance evaluations can be frustrating.
Business process needs to be improved and streamlined…

Reliable technology that supports day to day work both at the office and when working from home.  On multiple occasions, my work has not saved properly and resulted in lost time and resources to the BCPS, my organization and my work unit. Updated and reliable technology would also be a recommendation for all medium-large size boardrooms across government.
Better recognition of those who do volunteer work within the Ministry.  Sometimes it’s a significant amount of work and recognition goes a long way to making sure that people stay aboard.

I enjoy the work I do and the people I work with. I suggest some team building to improve the team morale and some leadership courses for the entire group. Maybe a session or two on effective coaching.

Suggestion: Improve the consistency of messaging from Executive. Despite excellent efforts by Executive to share planning activities with staff, self-imposed deadlines related to the ‘functional review’ and strategic planning have been missed with no follow-up message addressing why this occurred and future plans for the functional review.  By simply ceasing to refer to this major initiative in recent communications, Executive has lost some credibility with staff with regards to whether activities that are announced in the future will be fully committed to and realized. A simple acknowledgement of a change to plans or priorities would remedy this.
Need to improve ability to deal with problematic / non-performing employees more effectively. Need to be able to deal with absenteeism in an effective way - doesn't appear to be a solution.
Management being open to ideas from subordinates.
Provide stand-up desks.

...I have heard that other units/branches have higher employee satisfaction, and therefore, retention rates. I feel this stems from a combination of things, one being entrenched employees who project very negative attitudes toward both management and in general. This has a very negative impact on newer employees and fosters a very toxic work environment...
…There is quite a bit of noise in my unit (work next to a call centre) and can find it quite difficult to concentrate…

Change the physical layout of the space to maximize relationship building and collaboration (particularly at the Branch level) and also [be] inclusive of those working at [other offices] who are doing similar work.

The office space is very bland and colourless. I feel that should statement walls around the office be painted in public service colours (Blue & yellow) and even in chalk paint (to share ideas and write reminders) the office would feel more progressive and current with work place trends in Vancouver. The public service offers fulfilling work, with competitive pay and benefits, but could stand to compete with the private sector in terms of office atmosphere.
Decision-making processes seem really slow right now due to the change in government. No one seems to know how to get a decision made in my work unit.

"We are faced with a long list of projects to respond to the OAG recommendations and to meet the Minister's mandate letter.  We will need additional resources to accomplish this.  In the interim we need to develop a strong project management culture to justify the extra resources and to guide projects to a successful conclusion. On the positive side we have accomplished a lot from where we were..."
"Better integration across branches… and across divisions. Where can we help/learn from each other to produce better results as a ministry."

I think that the knowledge/communication between the different branches could be improved.  A better understanding of what each branch is responsible for as it relates to our own work would be beneficial as we frequently have overlapping issues but aren't aware of it.  This could also result in consistency of procedures between branches.

"It would be nice to have more regular and less formal communications from senior Executive as to changes in strategic direction.  It is getting much better though, strides have been made to be more inclusive."
"Improvements to the aging building including HVAC fixes and lighting improvements. Bathrooms and lunchrooms are becoming worn down and drab."
"Accelerate advancement of upgrade of computer hardware (especially ThinkPads)."
"Executive Director should take a look at bringing decisions forward in a more timely manner…"

"Staffing... New staff ensure projects are significant, effective, relevant, and meet the high standard our organization has a reputation for delivering. With an increased and diversified program mandate and a busier industry, current staff meet goals but are spread thin. We could do more."
"I would like to see the Executive be more transparent and communicative. We are rarely informed about the results and content of internal and external meetings that shape our business."
"Provide a clear vision for fulfilling the Minister's mandate letter, in particular the requirement for independent oversight."
"Discuss our Vision, Mission and Goals in more detail. Have a more participatory Service Plan development."

"Improve communication from Executive regarding current decisions, issues and strategies that affect the overall organization.  What are Executive working on now, what are the urgent items that need to be addressed, what is coming from the Minister's office or other parts of government?  Some might be confidential, but even just saying that no more can be said on those items would be valuable.  This would help staff know more about urgent priorities and how their own work fits in."
"The supervisors should identify and establish reasonable workloads to prevent staff from becoming overloaded."
"We really need new office furniture and everyone should have the option of a sit/stand desk for their well-being."

"This Ministry has a wealth of high performing individuals, as well as very diverse work units.  It would be wonderful if there were more opportunities to develop new skills by offering stretch assignments and more experiential learning opportunities which may be outside an employee's specific current role or branch."
"We need more administrative staff. Basic functions like filing, letter writing, issuing minutes, notices, etc. are not done well."

I wish there was more education available for staff at the [lower classification] range. None of the education starts until you're a supervisor and if that is not a position you can come into there is no way to get the knowledge needed to move up.

"Online access to full-text content of technical journals is as important for BC Public Service Science Officers as attending technical meetings, workshops and courses, which require out-of-province and international travel for maintaining their high-level of expertise and professional development."

"Improve EMPR's relationship with BC First Nations and improve our reputation with other ministries and the public. Perhaps by considering more emphasis on improving sustainability and reducing our environmental impacts."
Change management process and communications regarding change.

"Better computer and software options for technical work...Better support for health and well-being. Specifically, standing desks for everyone rather than a convoluted process that requires a serious medical condition. Standing desks do not need to be expensive hydraulic desks."

"For me, it's the communication piece from the top down. I understand how my work affects the day-to-day operations of my work unit, however, I rarely have a sense of the direction of my ministry as a whole... More communication = more effective work."

Improving and/or implementing better software. While the Ministry of Energy, Mines, and Petroleum Resources isn't far behind on GIS software, many of the useful software provided by ESRI is unavailable to our organization. This is especially prevalent when compared to other organizations outside of the government and sometimes within the government… These are useful tools that would allow our reach to stretch beyond its current capacity.

"Work space is a problem. We are short on space, it's very noisy which is a problem for completing technical reviews. My desk/office space could be better set up to help with ergonomics. A second screen would be helpful in completing day to day work. A standing desk would be helpful to alleviate chronic back issues associated with sitting all day."

Adequate resourcing and staffing levels. The increasingly complex nature of regulatory control as public and First Nation expectations of rising standards and engagement increase are putting considerable work, personal and mental stress on [staff] to the point where the Province is only protected from the ethical and health liability of its under resourcing by the work spirit and commitment of the staff.
"Replace some of the critical software that we need to complete the majority of the work that our unit does."

"Professional development funds to allow us to take short courses or to attend training. Training with the public service can be good but is just fluff compared to external training opportunities. Along with that, allow us to attend conferences even if we don't present and approve ahead of time to allow us to plan and coordinate with others properly."
"Workload management of staff."

Improve branding/promotion/transparency of the work we do. My organization is fair, diverse and highly ethical. The public should understand the work we do better, including our success and challenges.
"Improvements to office configuration to mitigate noise/distraction from adjacent teams and common areas to improve focus and efficiency."

I feel that the work processes are complicated and take too much time to complete. We need to work towards increasing efficiency and time management… Too many software platforms not working together are used in my work and slowing down the processes. We need a single software having access to all the information necessary for issuing a permit or an inspection report, for communication with proponents, FN, including for sending letters.

It would be great if the volume of work could decrease, so we don't always have to be in the survival mode, rushing from one thing to the other.   It would be fantastic to actually be able to calmly do some research to make the best decision possible.
More realistic workloads and deadlines…Better planning so everything isn't done in a rush in the two months before fiscal year end.

Better understanding from Senior Executive regarding the complexities and challenges faced by the individual organizational units in fulfilling the Ministry Service Plans and objectives. Walk a mile in a line worker’s shoes to have an appreciation for what they do, challenges they face and why.
More timely communication from Executives would be much appreciated, in lieu of last minutes tasks.  It would be nice to put faces to the names of Executives in the divisions and the ministry level .
Our facilities were built in [date] and don't support a modern approach to service delivery.
My organization needs to hire at least one full time employee, possibly two, for my immediate work area instead of relying on contractors that were to be a temporary situation.

Better, up-to-date tools for employees. It is so frustrating to be prevented from doing your best work by the outdated technology you're given. Nothing fancy, just mobile devices that are actually easily portable, Wi-Fi that works throughout entire building… collaboration tools that can be used with people outside government, online meeting software that doesn't have constant technical glitches, being able to get a workstation replaced when yours stops working properly (which right now takes forever or is virtually impossible), changing jobs without 3 days of no computer or email access, etc. Every public servant I know wants to do great work and will, if you'll just give them what they need to do it.
To better understand the organization, how areas interact with each other, I have been curious about the overall organization chart for the branch, but there doesn't seem to be one.

We must be able to get approval to hire an appropriate number of extra staff before taking on a considerable number of new projects in addition to keeping up with daily client orders.  At present staff are in more of a reactive mode than proactive mode which leads to stress and mistakes being made.

The constant changing priorities are so hard to keep up with. Management should get together and be on the same page with competing priorities instead of the constant struggle back & forth. So much time is wasted flipping from one urgent priority to another and back again.
Allow for additional resources to meet requirements which will reduce workload and increase performance.
Eliminate the use of targets and quotas as a performance measurement, and the subsequent shaming that occurs when targets and quotas are not met.
I would like to see Managers do more, be more involved in helping staff to figure out a career path.

More opportunity in rural BC and outside of Victoria and Lower Mainland. I live in Northern BC and not many opportunities for advancement in my community - I will have to move, but that is not a good option for me.  More virtual positions and more virtual TA's would be great to broaden my horizons.

More investment in staff training.  Employees are the most valuable asset within any company.  Taking the time and effort to maintain an employee's skills is smart and effective investment.  I hope to see training opportunities a priority in the near future.  Providing the employee with the ability to attend conferences related to their job is essential.  Cuts to employment training opportunities have effectively increased risk for employee's to be effective and stimulate growth in their chosen field.

It's tough to retain part-time ‘as and when required’ employees. We hire them, train them and then they move on.  It takes long time to fill that vacant position.  The remaining staff's workload increases which is stressful. We need more relief budget so we can assist other offices when these staffing shortages result and become a burden on remaining staff.

Strong and consistent leadership…There is no consistency as each person comes in with different ideas and wanting to change process, priorities, etc., and it seems as though nothing is ever completed or decisions made. Staff are constantly having to prove their value each time there is a change in Executive, and it is extremely draining.

One of the issues is that we are often given work that we are told is a priority and it sits with Executive for a very long time and either doesn't move forward or takes a great deal of time to move forward. It would be nice to receive feedback regarding on what they receive, even if it is just to say this the work is on hold. There seems to be a lot of hurry up and then wait for a long time. One way to alleviate this issue is to re-prioritize what needs to go to Senior Executive.  Some decisions I believe could be delegated to the Executive Director or Director.

It would be nice to see more of a sense of community at the workplace. More extracurricular activities during work and after working hours to help team building and camaraderie within the organization…
Be more realistic by understanding the organization's capabilities and capacity for change before setting vision and goals.

I would really appreciate some attention for my and my team's work environment. We sit in a very, very noisy space, where it is open to the noise of our entire building. It is difficult to concentrate. Our space is wide open about two and a half stories above us, so lighting levels and temperature fluctuate wildly.
