I love my job very much, but this is by far the worst space I've had. It is the only thing that would make me consider moving to a different position, or outside of government.
Implement a training / orientation program for new employees, i.e. a kind of passport to learning to ensure that all new staff receives consistent training.
Confirm governance roles and responsibilities in the program area to clarify who has the authority for different types of decision-making - at all levels.
Focus on building culture. We have lots of new and often young staff.

Despite my post-secondary education, I feel trapped in my current career stream. I want to move into [a different area] but the experience requirements for entry level positions disqualify me and I have no idea where I can get this type of experience. It is likely that I am going to be forced to leave the public service in the near future due to a lack of opportunities to gain experience (i.e. job-shadowing, training, etc.).

Better communication from Executive to staff.  Communication doesn't need to be formal and Executives don't have to know all the answers.  An informal update, letting staff know what's happening now, can really go a long way.

More space/expansion is very much needed. Currently we are well over capacity in terms of work stations. The constant need to share/needing to borrow work stations can distract from work needed for both myself and colleagues.
To really listen to the feedback provided by employees. Don't ask if you are not willing to listen and/or act on.

The heating in our building is often on high which leads to a stuffy, uncomfortable work environment and contributes to higher than normal levels of stress. The heat is not controlled in [location] and not able to be adjusted. This leads to a waste of energy, taxpayer funds and windows have to be opened to provide relief. While this may seem like a small thing to most, as an employee I can say that our team feels the negative effects daily.
Better software to decrease the frequency of service delays caused by program glitches/failures.

… Communication between teams and business units needs to be improved. Things are often very segregated with little to no information about other teams, what they do, and who to contact with questions. There is a tendency to create too many silos that prevent open communication and collaboration between units.

The work performed by CITZ is very operational and supportive in nature to other core ministries, thus, the work CITZ does, primarily in IT and Real Estate, is heavily prescribed.  Creating a true vision for the ministry to shape it from an operational to a strategic ministry would help evolve the work we do from supportive to transformative.  It would create engaging and rewarding opportunities and inspire the workforce.

Resolve workplace issues instead of moving people around because the problem doesn't disappear - it creates them for the new environment  - Management needs a stronger backbone to deal with discrimination issues instead of saying, 'I don't want to know.'
Management should consider avoiding favoritism (or perceived as) in the organization.  Staff who insulted and disrespected others got recognized and promoted.

I think it is important for my organization to focus on the morale in our work place. Better morale will cause their employees to be more content and work and cause us to want to work harder and go above and beyond what is expected of us.
Please replace the old chairs with ergonomic chairs.  We spend most of the day sitting, and this would be a big improvement…

It would be great to revamp our working space - there is a lot of wasted space and a lot of things that are no longer needed as we head more and more into the digital world (we don't need 2 filing cabinets and shelves, for instance). I think that space can be utilized better for stand-up desks and better desk lights for those of us who don't have natural light.

As much as it is a great thing that we are moving more and more services online, I think it is important to remember that there are members of our society who are not online; either by choice or by circumstance. I think it is important that we make all our services available on paper/in person, so as to increase access to ALL our citizens.

Overly complex procedures for what should be simple tasks/requests consume a disproportionate amount of time.  One of very few drawbacks of working for BC Public Service but has a major impact on job satisfaction.
"Equipment - staff need computers, ergo desks, chairs, phones and office waiting rooms need computers that work for clients to use..."

"Workload is far too high, meaning that I do not have time to focus on key aspects of my role such as supervision and leadership.   Additional resources are needed.   Related to this, supervisors and managers spend proportionately way more time than we did in the past providing status updates and seeking approval for decisions from senior management.   This overhead should be eliminated, and supervisors and managers should be empowered to make decisions appropriate to their classification without having to seek additional approvals.   "
"There is too much emphasis on quantity of work done vs quality of work done."
"I would like to see higher dividers between the work cubicles.  I find the open concept very noisy to work in while trying to provide respectful service to clients on the telephone "
"Training for relevant work topics that relate to poverty."

Move away from open concept pods to allow for more privacy and concentration without noise and distraction to more effectively deal with clients. Or at least to provide better sound blocking headsets for virtual workers.

Employees are your strongest resource... the ministry has forgotten how to value us.  We need a proper pay scale for the complex nature of our jobs, re-class or proper wage increases... 1% is shameful. Proper benefits and better retirement packages.
"More Face to Face contact with clients we serve."

When requests are made to Executive for approvals or direction it can take weeks to get an answer or no answer or direction is provided. This has a highly negative impact for staff and clients especially for those working in specialized services.

"I can't express how we need consistency of our procedures/processes throughout the offices within the region. This would reduce conflict/ upsets with clients not understanding our different rules/procedures for each office within a local area."
Please pay us more for the work that we do. [Classification level] is a very low level Grid that has not kept pace with inflation and Cost of Living in BC.

"Wages and benefits need to be more in line with other provinces and job types in the private sector.  I would give Public Service a very high ranking if public servants were financially compensated fairly. "
"Increase resources. Our workload is unmanageable and more and more keeps being added, every quarter, every year. We need more people to help get the work done."

"So many things have improved since 2006 but there is much to do in regard to focussing, truly focussing on our client's and staff's well-being. The Executive message might be they are focussed on our client's needs but in reality our citizens are often left by the wayside so statistics can be met. This is truly an embarrassment. Executives are fed by supervisors and managers and quotas are met statistically to please the powers that be. But  workers are stressed out trying to meet unrealistic quotas and clients in turn miss out of citizen centered services."

"Increase safety of employees and clients, both inside and outside buildings. Update physical work environment; many offices are old and in need of upgrade: including old and not ergonomic work stations, bad heating/cooling units, disgusting carpeting, etc. Some of these offices are embarrassing, with mice, bugs, stained and broken furniture! Make employment accessible to all, physical access within buildings, as well as computer system access for those who require assistive technology. Many jobs are inaccessible within public service. More virtual meetings should be possible within higher up/Executives, eliminating travel costs and environmental issues. Those who work on virtual teams should have the opportunity to meet in person."
"I'm so exhausted by the non-stop issues I endure related to ICM and software. There isn't enough time to follow up with reports to SDPR Support or even report issues, half the time. "
"Please continue to provide opportunities for mentoring and career enhancement.  It would be great to learn about other facets of public service through an internal 'job fair'..."

"Need more opportunities to mentor/act in positions of my interest. We have highly skilled staff working as EAW/CSW who want to get ahead but the opportunities aren't available. ie. no plans to let CSW/SAS into management roles, only way to move is if they have EAW experience, which is short sided if they've had management experience in other roles outside public service."
"Ensuring our vision/goals are supported through staffing and technology as the external environment changes.  Being even more focused on client experience and service quality."

My organization has great ideas and good high-level processes...but I know we do not have enough employees to do the work as well as possible. Would like to see all Directors, Exec Directors shadow the lowest level employees to understand how much work is being transferred downwards and how complicated it is to do it correct.
"Hire more staff.  There is too much work for too few people."

"Our workstations are not the best to accommodate the sitting we do. The open office concept is challenging with making phone calls, interviewing, meetings, etc due to noise and other activities.  Better equipment/work tools to assist with this!"

"Continuous Training in social subjects - such as People's reactions to Trauma, Anger, Mental Health, Addictions Behaviours, Competence, Assertiveness (as opposed to 'punishing') Motivational Interviewing etc..... A few good tools in your toolbox makes the work so much easier..."

"The division is too split up between multiple locations and cities. It makes if very difficult to work collaboratively and communicate successfully. There are many events, meetings, learning and face-to-face opportunities which are missed because of the separation. Because of the type of work we do and how important it is for our unit to work together, it is vital we are in the same location."

More competitive wages for non-supervisory technical positions. It seems the only way to move ahead in your career is to follow a leadership path. The overall quality of the research/technical work suffers as people of high calibre leave the public service in BC for better paying and more interesting opportunities elsewhere… Ironically, since these technical skills are often still needed, my division uses contractors to fill their IT and project management needs at much higher cost overall without developing internal capacity.

Open placement of jobs geographically across BC. Centralizing offices may save on leasehold costs but individuals living outside those physical locations are prevented from career advancement if unable/unwilling to relocate. All eggs in the Vancouver/Victoria egg baskets is inequitable to the Public Service as a whole and misses out on expertise from outlying areas.
"I feel the pay we get does not meet the job requirements, our pay is one of the lowest in Canada, and we have the highest cost of living."

In order to do our work well, it is important to have necessary, up-to-date tools. We are constantly fighting for proper chairs, pens, books, monitors, locations, etc. A welcoming environment can make the difference of one staying and leaving the organization. Workers have so much to offer with their experience, dedication, and passion for BC Public Service- they deserve to be recognized with proper tools to do their job well, rather than feel like a burden or underpaid each time they look at their workstation(s).

"I am disappointed with the direction that the ministry is heading, with the push of client services towards virtual avenues.  I see the benefits of having those services available, but it is not beneficial for a lot of our clients with multiple barriers.  Pushing them away from face-to-face contact towards virtual services that they have difficulties accessing and/or using, is not respectful to them and the struggles they face.  They deserve to be heard, respected, and their needs addressed in the best way our ministry is able to provide.   I would like the ministry to focus more on face-to-face service provision, to provide a more personal human experience.  As a trained worker, having that face-to-face contact makes work more enjoyable"
"Workload review. Better pay for the amount of work. A review of employee benefits. 100% pay for sick time, given that employees are stressed by their jobs."
"Cost of living increases that are equal to inflation."

The tool at the contact centre to take calls (ICE) frequently fails: dropping calls, calls going silent where I cannot hear client -often mid call- (when this happens I have to log off, restart, and call the client back) and this greatly affects my ability to do my job as it happens on a daily basis. Clients become frustrated which can already be a hazard of the job (clients who have grievances with the Ministry often take it out on the workers who serve them). I would like to have access to a quiet room in the office to de-stress. This does not exist in my office. Gender representation in ICM: there is no way to easily identify a trans client when they call in because ICM only allows bio gender, and only has M or F options.
"A better alignment between speaking about the importance of work/life balance and the actual amount of work that needs to be done."
More mentoring opportunities would be beneficial.
It would be nice if computer network speed was more reliable. The times that I decide to do something else or am distracted because my computer is slow are not infrequent.
Provide market comparable salaries within IM/IT (comparable to industry not to government).
Salary increases that recognize the increasing demands and high work performance of excluded staff.
Before implementing new [software], make sure that the software outputs meet ministry standards and we have the computers, network and training to run the software.
With the change in government, we no longer have a long term strategic Provincial Transportation Plan. We need one.
Allow for purchase of ergonomically suitable furniture, much of the office furniture is 15-20 years old and in poor condition.

More people. The members of my team are stressed by new and expanding demands on their time, yet no one is available to backfill if they are sick, on vacation or asked to perform new duties. I have concerns about their health and the possibility that the team will 'break' if the trend to 'do more work with less people' continues.

More routinely carpet vacuuming and dusting of workstations. There is a buildup of black dust on the desk after a week which can't be good for health or people with allergies. Also pickup of garbage at works stations should be reinstated and much more convenient than having to keep going to the lunchroom to throw any garbage.
"Please more staffing resources. It is one thing to be underpaid, but expected to take on more and more duties is not sustainable."
Support the creation of new positions to provide growth opportunities to retain developing employees. This would also enable workload distribution and relieve stress.

Wages for Engineers should be increased to match those of Federal and Local Government. We lose a lot of good staff to jobs with Federal and Local Government because they pay 30% more for the same work and skill sets.

Proper training, mentoring, job shadowing, modules -- Staff need to have a formal training program rather than figure it out as you go. Presently it is difficult to make the decisions we need to make as we never have the complete information - it is based on learning who might have the information you require and knowing the questions to ask. It is very time consuming and frustrating. Having proper training and a central location/person for info would be very beneficial, especially as my position requires knowledge in many different areas at the same time.

Commensurate benefit package and pay scale to reflect the economic reality currently overstraining modest family budgets regarding housing, health and wellness, food staples, hydro, petroleum, insurance etc.

To develop a focus on continued training and updating in a classroom situation with fellow workers from differing work units. This would keep us unified, updated on changes, knowledgeable, and most importantly it would keep us engaged from the top down. It's important to know that our leadership wants us to be professional and that they care enough to have us do a good job by giving us the information and tools we need.
Accountability to the hiring managers that disregard pre-requisites, certifications and experience, allowing potential new employees to be granted an interview.
Focus on your people (i.e. training and development). This will create a happier and more efficient workplace and improves worker engagement.
Office space is limited or does not meet the work unit needs. Office furniture is often outdated and provided as used from other organizations.
Have comparable wages for the same type of work as other organizations.

"We are severely understaffed.  Workloads are unmanageable.  Our ministry is amazing at what it does, but it doesn't seem like we are heard at upper levels that we need more boots on the ground - and not just dollars to hire consultants - real staff.  I love what I do, but I can't maintain my current workload."
I would recommend that there are measures in place to ensure that all competitions, whether for included or excluded positions, are run fairly.  This would greatly improve morale in the workplace.

… Most importantly, the department should focus on reducing the levels of unnecessary bureaucracy that work has to flow throw before it gets approved/completed. There are a lot of unnecessary delays in both receiving assignments and in getting them out the door once they are done.
Develop clear business plans specific to business units and ensure employees understand what their role and accountabilities are toward the success of the organization.

Some processes are unnecessarily onerous. The internal hiring process is extremely onerous for applicants and hiring managers.  For TAs especially, a more flexible approach could encourage movement, learning and innovation within the public service while reducing costs of hiring.  The existing process rewards those who are good at interviewing not those who would be successful employees.

One thing: Improved Pay and Benefits ... I do feel valued as a public servant in the job that I do and I feel proud to work for the BC government and the contribution I make to this province. However, the level of pay and benefits for the work I do and the cost of living where I live falls short. I feel government wages in the province/region I live in are chronically low compared to other provincial governments - especially when you compare it to the cost of living where I reside. Benefits could also be improved - especially dental and vision, and also allowing for at least 5 full sick days a year (without having to top up).

The BC Public Service needs to be realistic about the wages that are paid.  It is difficult to retain employees or provide incentive to new or potential employees when the wages do not reflect all the work  and time commitment that is made when working for the public service.

Better staff training of their job duties and responsibilities. Too many staff seem to 'winging it' when they start a new role. Supervisors need to spend more time with staff ensuring procedures are known and being followed.

"Define the organizational objectives and conduct detailed evaluation of them effectively in the existing operational model and supporting organizational structure. Identify the transformative opportunities and needs and put them into action..."
Be honest and open with new positions.  Stop being sneaky and slipping people into new roles or hiring people without giving others the change to apply even if it is a lateral.
Our organization appears to be chronically short staffed.  This has led to a large number of employees feeling overworked and leads to more departures.

More face to face meetings with a chance to bond with other work units in other regions to form a better relationship with them. I feel it would help with knowledge transfer and learning opportunities.
"Consistency on how people in comparable positions operate in all other areas of the province vs how people in our work unit operate..."

The Ministry puts very little effort into internal communication of vision, mission, and goals, and does not push the departments and branches to develop vision, mission, and goals specific to their business area.  It is very difficult for those not involved in direct maintenance and management of roadways to see their work reflected in the Ministry.  There are no meaningful performance measures collected or reported by the Ministry.  The measures included in the annual service plan report are at best high level, and barely connect to the day to day activities of Ministry staff…

Making sure succession planning is in place for all work units. Should a staff member leave who is the go-to knowledge for a specific project that knowledge is shared and learning opportunities are in place for other members of the unit.
Improved flexibility in purchasing desks, chairs, and other office improvements. This is something our Ministry routinely scores low on and nothing seems to change.
LEANing processes to reduce bottlenecks and wasteful tasks.

My Organization needs to focus on the work units that bring the most value to the organization by hiring the right amount of people to do the workload demands of that work unit. Many work units don't have enough staff for workload.

A typical complaint but I believe compensation is the largest issue.  Work life balance is a necessity to most,  but as a young individual with significant freedom, I don't see the Public Service as competitive in today's market. There is a significant gap when I compare my compensation to friends/relatives in applicable fields. What I see more and more is workload increasing for individuals in this organization - due to retirement/loss of staff - while compensation stays the same. Benefits are not competitive, many of my friends have much better benefits at their entry jobs. You will continue to see more of my generation leave for private industry, as is happening with my younger coworkers now, if this does not change.
My work site is outdated and not big enough for the work we do or staff we have.  The ergonomics of my work site are terrible and must be improved for comfort and health.
Improve the hiring practices. Current practices do not necessarily hire the best person for the job, but the one that's answers scored the most points.

Software and hardware within the government are way behind the times. There are too many hoops to jump through in order to update computers, programs or data collection software. This slows production down and reduces efficiency of workers.

To get support from Executive to hire for positions which will replace an FTE that has indicated their intention to retire well in advance of retirement to further support knowledge transfer. For example, allowing a 3 month shadow plan and not posting the position shortly before people retire.
Need to continually strive for province wide continuity in the development and application of policy.

More visibility and direct communication from the DM… More Executive leadership, communication and support for government processes and timelines to reduce number of 'rush' assignments (e.g. service plan, budget process, correspondence, briefing material preparation, estimates preparation).
...Verbalized goals for the ministry and the work units. Clear direction on priorities and vision on how new priorities mesh with existing policies and programs...

"Workload.  I believe this can be accomplished by reviewing & adjusting the work to be achieved more efficiently as opposed to more staff to continue doing things the same way!  There are better ways to do the job effectively & maintain a manageable workload but expectations may need to change.  Need to ask why we do what we do at all levels . . ."
"Executive should demonstrate greater level of respect for rank and file staff contributions to Ministry's success."

"Workload and scope of work has increased as has the rapid pace of the work.   Staff strive to work to this expectation but are challenged when the probability of being in the 'doghouse' is greater than recognition.  A pattern exists at senior levels not to recognize the knowledge, dedication or successes of staff across AGRI, but instead to criticize others' outputs.   Negativity does not breed courage / innovation..."

"The performance of central agencies... add limited value, increase costs by forcing compliance with poorly designed processes and cause repeated and unnecessary delays. Their roles need to be at least partially decentralized."
"More chance for advancement within our Ministry.  You know you have the skills and abilities to advance, but you don't get that opportunity."
…Interface with Executive as a whole difficult - working on a more respectful and empowering interface with EDs should be a focus.

"Communicate, communicate, communicate.  Internally, across and with outside stakeholders.  I should not find out about our programs from another Ministry or the public.  Executive needs to walk the talk and show up in areas outside Victoria and  Abbotsford.  Open your eyes and see how phenomenal your staff are.  For many, the job,and not the Vision or Executive,  are keeping them in the job.  I am very engaged, yet my scores are low.  I know greatness is possible."
"Frank evaluation of our available resources with a goal of focussing efforts on the priority tasks we can do well and a cease of other tasks with an open communication of this to all clients.  "

"Continue to encourage and allow dialogue between staff and Executive, either by webinar/conference call meetings on somewhat regular schedules.  We do appreciate when Executive comes for a visit to the regional locations. It helps us to feel 'in the loop', informed, up to date, and part of the conversation about where our organisation is going and what we should be doing. "

"Better data management and associated systems (for example:  better online, mobile and e-service tools, just to mention a few).  This is restrained and complicated by central agencies who dictate what you can do, but are not responsible for business outcomes..."

"... salaries and facilities (office tools, equipment) are not in line with (i.e they are below) those of other ministries I have worked in.  This creates a challenge in recruiting and maintaining people and in offering a competitive and comparative working environment."

"Our directorship is in need of a major attitude/personnel overhaul. There is such an atmosphere of 'the Executive is important and you are all just peons' here it is unbelievable, so while I love the science and the diversity in my day to day duties, I would jump ship in a heartbeat if a good opportunity came along..."

"Workshops on how to prepare for and seek out career advancements would be great. Some supervisors provide valuable insights into this but it would provide inspiration and guidance to have a ministry or government wide focus on this. It would help with staff retention and makes a big difference to how staff perceive their future opportunities and what they can do about seizing them..."
"Better align professional development opportunities with the employee's job description and performance, public service expectations."

"Ensure that we have the physical tools to do our jobs well. Ensure people have access to ergonomically suitable work spaces and have better access to  office equipment (chairs, standing desks, lamps, etc.) when needed.  Install projector and desktop computer in at least one staff boardroom at [location address] to facilitate remote meetings between staff in branches split between [locations]."
Private offices would be nice. I was in an office and now in a cubicle and often many of us are on different conference calls and it is difficult to concentrate on my call due to noise.

"Better communication of strategic priorities or minister priorities that is occurring within and across the two divisions. Currently, the two divisions work very much in isolation of each other and is somewhat of a competitive environment has been created which is not healthy."

"I believe there is a tendency to make business decisions that are politically based and result in inefficiencies and have the effect of delaying the decision that needed to be made until a later date."
"Newer computer systems and programs would enhance my work as well as streamline our processes."

"Executive needs to focus their attention on connecting with their branch employees more frequently. In addition, when connecting with branch employees, the communication needs to be more open and transparent and cognizant of tone. Branch staff are not feeling heard or appreciated for their work and in a branch where staff are mostly remote/mobile, communication is key to success. There needs to be more emails, phone calls, and in person and/or Lync meetings between staff and Executive. More sharing of information and 'what's happening' in the branch, and more money available for remote staff to meet each other in person and connect as a unified team."

"Allow staff to spend more time in the field, on farms and meeting farmers. There are many staff that are working in AGRI, but they never get to actually go out of the office and see anything involving farming."
"Hardware options - laptop vs. desktop, for example."

"There are 6 branches in this Ministry and all 6 seem to have no idea what processes and procedures the others have in place.  The silos in this Ministry are astounding and greatly impact the work we do and the clients we serve..."

"A ministry-level systematic review of mandate and other strategic initiatives and priorities and how they have changed or not changed since new government. Delivering this out and down the chain to allow manager to engage with unit staff on where we are and where we are going would be incredibly supportive during mandate change and supporting ongoing alignment as new initiatives and priorities come up. "
"Continue to evaluate the organization's work load (i.e., submissions and cases) and add staff as necessary to maintain adequate turnaround times and workload for all."
"More funding for FTEs to bring staff capacity up to a reasonable level needed to do the job well."

"Personal growth and professional development needs to be more meaningful - not just more. Employ staff according to their qualifications, skills and personal qualities.  Provide staff with projects that are more challenging and they can identify with…"
Improve relations between ADMs - appears to be overly competitive. Improve information and direction from Minister's office.

"Workload -- there is a lack of resources to complete tasks and as a person who has integrity in my work, I end up taking on too much and working over time to ensure deadlines and tasks are completed."

It seems to be the case that decisions are often made in conversations at the [Executive level] that do not flow down to the policy staff level, even when it concerns a project that policy staff is leading.
"Dual screens would make working with different data sets easier."

"Offer training opportunities for employees to try different positions within the ministry. As well as, offer supervisor training for those interested in moving up into the management or Executive team…"
More funding to be allocated to training and development.
Faster computer and stand up work stations
Improve new employee orientation throughout the public service.  Currently this is very haphazard and new employees feel lost and if that goes on long enough, we lose them.
"Need to continue to develop consistency across departments regarding HR policies."

Utilizing the more senior staff to help with the training of new staff to ensure they make the right decisions and understand the reasons why things are done.  More knowledge and insight to why, how things are done.
Increase the amount of boardrooms available for meetings. Upgrade tools available for staff (computers/phones etc)
"Keep providing opportunities for staff to work on projects that cross multiple branches."
Focus on identifying goals and objectives and sharing them with employees in the organization. Then prioritize the work to support those goals and objectives, allocating resources accordingly.

"Office space, tools and equipment to do my job could be improved upon. Providing staff with the proper tools to do their job, not only within my organization, but across government as a whole could be improved upon. As public servants it is not appropriate to have 'deluxe' offices, tools and equipment. However, we shouldn't be expected to work with 'less' than what is acceptable business standards either."

"Executive need to become leaders by example. Accountable, communicative and clear on the directions and decisions that affect each public servant. If they are not held accountable, then often the pressure is placed on all the staff under their direction to meet those demands…”

"… Improve the workplace tools. For example supply reasonable quality computers. This past year is the worst ever in many years for degradation of and inability of the laptops, printers and so called wireless connectivity. We are now constantly waiting for IT. Everyone jokes about it. What a waste…"

It is incredibly disappointing to see the actions at the Executive level that do not reflect the values of the BC Public Service on a regular basis.  It is equally disappointing to see the Executive leaders making demands that not supported by adequate resourcing or reasonable deadlines.  Executives expect 24/7 work from employees and do not balance work-life needs to their staff.

"Provide more 'real' opportunities for training (time and budget to everyone equally). Training opportunities seems to always go to certain people/types of positions. The training budget isn't allocated evenly to all departments.  In addition, the growth opportunities in the branch are not equally offered - they are always given to the same 'star' people…”
I don't have a clear path to promotion within my organization. Since I would like to stay, I would like to have more internal growth opportunities available.

Middle management in my division is very poor. There is a lack of leadership and direction, as well as attention being pulled to new and shiny projects while neglecting the ongoing work of the division. This has led to infighting between and within teams.
"Team-to-Team communication.  Appears quite silo'ed.  Interpersonal and professional conflict has arisen because of this…"

Promote the Vision for our work unit and how we align with Ministries.  We rarely speak about Vision and Goals.  We seem to be focused on the process which is understandable but as someone on the floor it would be wonderful to link in what our long term goals are with the job that we are currently doing. I have an idea of what the long term model, vision and goals are but they are only based on my personal assumptions and not on what has been communicated out there.  Mission and Vision statements would be nice to have and the understanding of what type of hiring model we are working towards would be awesome.  Thank you.

It would be nice to see programs change and evolve based on need/metrics rather than just because.   I would love to have an idea pitched/sold to me rather than dictated. Currently we're told we're doing something and have to sell ourselves on the idea that it's going to add value to the program or project. Management and Exec should at least give us the positive points to fall back on and communicated to other Public Servants outside the program area.  Why does it feel like everyone is so busy all the time?

"More communication from our ADM about changes that are happening and why - not a canned e-mail after the fact. We need much more stability with our leadership.  I understand that movement and turnaround is a natural part of the career path but our work unit has had [several] different [managers] in the last year and [several] different directors in the last year.  This makes the work environment seem shaky and unstable."

Ergonomic desks and chairs.   To follow through with the results of an Ergo Assessment and provide the equipment needed or recommended after the assessment.    Remove some of the harsh overhead lights and allow desk lamps as staff complain of headaches

In my day to day work… it is glaringly apparent that very few work units within the Public Service (or even the BCPSA) take the appropriate amount of time to train managers/supervisors to understand their roles and responsibilities in relation to HR workflows. This is not their fault, resources are not easy to find without experience, many holes in process alignment go without being addressed, inconsistent adherence to policy/procedure across business units causes expectations to be unclear for staff and management.  The overall online information architecture is outdated and unwieldy - new hires and managers start out hamstrung.

Improve Executive direction and decision making. Decisions are not make in a timely way - long waits for direction, feedback - and then change direction. Timelines are set, then cut without notice. It's difficult to know where the goalposts are as they continually move - makes it difficult to be effective and efficient.
I strongly suggest that Executive engage more with actual employees.  So many of the 'working groups' that decide things are the same few people, time and time again. It's obvious and predictable.

The computers are very outdated.  They are constantly breaking, not connecting to the internet, and freezing.  We need new computers if we are to be able to continue our jobs.  Similarly, our office furniture and surroundings are in desperate need of updating.  We all sit on broken chairs with desks that don't lock and in offices that are too hot or too cold.  It is embarrassing to invite ministry clients to our offices.

The organization could focus on correcting issues around lack of professionalism. When these behaviors are not fixed, a precedent is set for new employees. Examples include under performance, tardiness and attitude.

There are too many silos and too many programs or projects that do not leverage the knowledge and skills embedded throughout the PSA. I would love to see more collaboration across business lines and a greater commitment to understanding how specific issues, programs or projects fit with (and impact) the bigger picture. Recognition of another business line's expertise can significantly impact the engagement of the employees in that line of business.

"Less Executive micro-managing, empower employees to deliver on their objectives. The current result is that there is no ability to innovate, because everything is being done to meet overly specific demands of Executive.  If Executive put trust in their employees to put action to the solutions, more creativity, more innovation and the deliver on the best interests of the citizens of BC. "
I would like to see more serious focus from supervisors on growth and development in order to gain the skills to be successful in a variety of other HR areas of the Public Service Agency.
I think changing the perception (real and perceived) that Leadership (all levels) are not approachable, willing to change themselves, or lead change.
Update computer equipment and provide better privacy in the office. Shared workspaces do not work well for client confidentiality.

"…More money should be put into the environments we work in, there has been a moratorium in ability to purchase new furniture for many year unless a medical requirement - this provides an unpleasant work environment for many as we are stuck with surroundings in bad shape ie: chairs, desk, etc. which makes for an unpleasant work environment.  We also underutilize a lot of our current space - some Ministries are holding onto large areas of unused space where other Ministries are struggling to cram more in through densification…"
Stronger focus on vision, mission, and goals so employees in the Agency feel they are working towards the same thing, together.

There is not a lot of opportunity for growth within [my work unit] and I feel that is why we have such a high turnover of staff. If there were opportunities to move to a [higher classification] then I feel more staff would stay.
"Communications for new initiatives to be well thought out, and delivered further in advance of change…”

…Communication. We have a lot of meetings and emails go out every single day...yet no one is properly informed. I feel like the lack of structure to said meetings is disrespectful to our time and defeats the purpose (to communicate important issues). Big news of promotions or structural changes are heard through the grape vine instead of emails or directly from the mouths of our supervisors and directors. If you are wanting buy-in from your staff you need to keep them in the loop not only with the changes but the reasoning behind them. Open and transparent communication is vital and necessary.

"Overall my organization is fantastic and I really enjoy working for them. It's a really great group and we work well together. The biggest issue is space, resources, and heat. Ergo assessment done months ago and recommendations sent, but nothing has really come out of that. A lot of my colleagues are sitting in really unsuitable chairs. Heat is also a frequent problem. As is lack of desk space…"
"… Ensure Team Leads understand the day to day workload for each position that they are supervising so they can better assess outcomes."
Training. There should be more interactive and hands-on  training rather than just watching a video. Everyone has a different learning style, so there should be multiple options to learn new skills.
Have clear ways of dealing with interpersonal team conflicts, and supervisors/managers willing to rapidly step in when they notice inappropriate behaviour.

"Less barriers for temporary auxiliary employees; some can be in T.A. status for months and miss integral opportunities for professional growth and networking, not to mention meeting coworkers in person for the first time..."
Stop squeezing people and equipment into smaller spaces.

Simplify processes. We are spending too much time and effort on things that do not result in any actual work done. Ensure that auxiliaries are able to give input and receive respect from the organization. Eg: none of our auxiliaries are able to participate in this survey as they are on lay-off at this time.

Action to address compensation inequities (especially relative compensation within the organization) to more appropriately reflect levels of responsibility and actual work demands. The organization seems to have established too 'flat' a compensation framework whereby positions of less responsibility are compensated comparatively higher, while positions of clearly much higher responsibility are compensated less than, equal to, or only marginally higher than the lower levels of responsibility. There are serious inequities which can only serve to undermine the organization over time.
A Vision that pulls together all of the various work areas and articulates what we are delivering for British Columbians.

“…Operational, administrative and approval processes are not documented but are expected to be adhered to. This model creates significant bottlenecks, frustration and confusion. An overhaul, perhaps with a third-party review of the operating model and processes, would yield significant benefit.”

Clear direction regarding priorities related to the new government.  We have been given some broad principles, but no direction or details.   In many cases, we are still following the priorities of the last government

Improve the salary for mid-managers in the organization as a means to recruit qualified and dedicated staff. Presently, many Union members being supervised by the mid-managers are making more, via OT, than the managers. The managers work more hours than 35 per week but do not receive compensation.
Provide more focus on the importance of [my division] in achieving Government's and my ministry's objectives, especially related to Indigenous Reconciliation.
Do not fear approving out of province travel for training as much professional and technical training is only available out of province

…We have poor quality, outdated hardware and software that results in significant loss of efficiency at work and increased frustration (stress). The organization feels [cheap] when it comes to replacing stuff that doesn't work… Tools and environment should make work efficient, not cause us to slow down and add stress to our work day. My one suggestion for the organization to improve the work environment, is to buy the tools we need, of at least the same quality as other ministries, and to stop the disparity between regional offices and headquarters.

Recognize that increased funding for projects and new initiatives and priorities require adequate staffing in regions to provide capacity to implement these projects. We can't just rely on partnerships and hiring consultants to do our work, especially because building relationships and maintaining partnerships, and managing contracts, carry significant workload. Particularly Planning and Conservation programs in regions are understaffed. New rangers are great, but we need to recognize that they need support and training from existing staff, and we are still a long way from providing number of staff needed to properly manage parks. I don't feel like Executive listens when staff repeatedly raise these concerns.

Provide a working budget early in the operating season, so that projects can be planned and executed effectively rather than providing the bulk of the budget towards the end of the year when most field projects can't get done.
First Nations engagement/consultation- coordinated with other work units to decrease load on FN communities and better link government projects, programs and issues.

"We need the IT tools to do our jobs effectively. There is not enough storage capacity, memory in the servers, laptops available, cables to run laptops. Too much time is spent worrying about IT capabilities to do our jobs…"
Sustainable pace of work

Simplify the approval processes for briefing notes and decision notes.  Too often a decision note goes through more than 4 or 5 levels of review with editorial changes along the way.  While the end result is an improved decision note, seldom does the actual recommendation change.  I think we need to question the value added by all the little tweaks along the way.

Hire new staff more quickly so that staff members are not overworked. Also, when staff are acting in positions, their base position should be filled. A staff member should not be responsible for completing the work of 2 positions. Staff will burn out if this practice continues.

"Clearly articulate vision, mission and goals with respect to what we as a division will be focusing on for next 1-3 years. And, most importantly, make a decision with respect to what will no longer be doing and reallocate those resources to improve capacity in our priority areas."

We need faster and more reliable systems and network connections, especially when it comes to GIS and data analysis.   I also do not like the LWS office design, I find it less collaborative because it's high density and we have to keep conversations to a minimum, meeting rooms are often fully booked, and it's hard to find where the mobile workers are. The A/V equipment in the meeting rooms are flakey too because there aren't enough adaptors or equipment goes missing.

Workload management! Workload increases every year with more being deferred or sidelined as a result - there is only so much time available. A project management approach to scoping and monitoring work may help. Best to scope out projects/work commitments and staff availability/expertise before committing to the work.

Listen to staff recommendations and comments. Pay attention when frustration in staff feeling ineffective becomes evident. Organization has a very high level of turnover and the issues underlying the turnover needs to be addressed if the organization is going to be effective.
Providing all middle managers opportunities to grow and develop through TA's and new assignments. Appears that these opportunities are provided to a select few and not made available equitably.

"There is an almost total lack of communication from Executive about what we are doing as an organization, what our colleagues in the organization are working on, what is expected of my work unit, how my unit's work and my own work fit into the bigger picture, and a [total] lack of communication on decisions that are made which directly affect my work. Most often I find out about higher level decisions on my files from [other staff or stakeholders] rather than from my own Executive. It’s embarrassing, frustrating, inefficient and, crucially, easily fixed!"

I would like to see staffing levels increase.  The pressures and expectations regarding environmental management continue to increase while staff numbers are still too low to truly be effective in delivering on our mandate.

Ensure that job classifications are fair.  It appears that staff in Victoria have higher classifications when the work they do is similar or less demanding then what is done in Districts/Regions.  Also, staff in Victoria seem to get hand selected for jobs whereas staff in Districts/Regions must compete.  Often jobs become available in Victoria and are filled before staff in Districts/Regions even find out about the opportunities

Generally, we need a greater vision for the ministry. We are about to double our population in 10 years. The impact on environment will be huge… I feel the vision we currently have is based on traditional ways. Not that this is 'bad' but it is not effective for the larger population base we will have over 10 years. We need an update…
Trust
At the Executive Director level there is an urgent need for more honesty and communication

The extended health coverage for dental and prescription drugs is very good. However, the coverage for massage therapy is terrible. Most desk-bound employees would benefit from a more comprehensive benefits package better covering massage therapy.  In addition, the cost of living in large cities has increased much faster than salaries. Many people in a single-income household are having a difficult time making ends meet. Perhaps its time to revisit the cost of living adjustment to our salaries.

Have conversations with the people who monopolize the privacy rooms for what seems to be all day long, seemingly day after day.  The privacy rooms are not 'first come, first serve private offices.'  Their usefulness depends on all staff respecting the rooms as 'use when you really need the privacy,' which is surely not all day every day.
Planning their work better to take into account the approval processes time. This will assist in lessening the workload stress.
More courses and training for staff, including auxiliaries.
Increase meaningful communication between layers of the organization and across the organization.
The switch to Great Western Life as the provider for extended health should be reviewed. Blue Cross coverage was much better for myself and my family.
Increased travel per diems, current amounts make it very difficult to eat without paying out of pocket.
Executive communication and leadership.

"Work effectively across Ministries. Environmental decisions are shared across many ministries…and they don't always coordinate. More importantly, they seem to be isolating their work and roles from one another, while staff should be encouraged to work collaboratively across ministries."
Clearer understanding of government's commitment and strategy to reach climate targets.
Workload is increasing but the resources/staff are not.
More administrative support would allow me to focus on my particular responsibilities.

Technical training on improving and fundamental elements of our work should be provided and the budget for training substantially increased. We regulate individuals who have a high degree of technical knowledge. If we ourselves continue to fall behind in our technical training, we cannot be expected to adequately regulate professionals who surpass us in their technical knowledge. The training gap between us and industry professionals must be reduced.
"Our organization lacks a unified vision with a plan to achieve it. Day to day work is fine, but there is no forward-moving path or goal(s) to achieve..."

"More opportunities for people to advance in their careers that doesn't necessarily involve management. The salary structure means that you have to move to management or higher to earn more money and grow in your career but not everyone is good at management. It would be so great if there were other opportunities to grow in your public service career (both professionally and financially in terms of compensation) below the management level. I find the current set up forces people into management and neglects to compensate people who do stellar work at more junior level."

"… CAS is a hierarchical top-down organization, with Executive clearly in control of the work and how it gets done. It is hard for ideas to flow upwards and little authority or responsibility at staff level. I am sure this is to some degree the political and ever changing nature of the file but perhaps more can be done to empower/ inspire staff to take ownership. It has been a busy time for climate but Executive appears more concerned about the tasks that need doing rather than the people doing them."

"The set-up at the [new building] is not working for most people. There might be individuals whose productivity has changed only slightly, but for most people it has caused noticeable decline in productivity. All the small things add up: finding a work station in the morning, setting up, trips to the locker, trips to a quiet room for every call, and most significantly, the sardine-like composition of mobile worker units, with absolutely no separation between workers or the walkway, which means every movement or conversation becomes a shared experience. Please make more mobile spaces intersperse the existing ones so mobile workers can concentrate and have a bit of privacy."
Our work loads are not manageable; we either need less work or more staff.
Better communicating strategic direction to staff to minimize inefficiencies in producing analysis.

As in every unit in Public Service the highly hierarchical nature of decision making makes it prone to have many inefficiencies. Certain decisions could certainly be decentralized. There are highly qualified people not in Executive positions that could/would be happy to take on these roles. In order to increase resilience and the adaptive capacity of our organization, 'real' efforts to decentralize certain processes, I believe, would be very welcomed.

Benefits, such as chiropractic, physiotherapy and massage are not comparable to other government agencies or private sectors. These are important things in stress relief and preventative maintenance. With the current coverage of these, people are likely to not use these services which can result in fewer sick days and better physical and mental health. I would be happy to pay a bit more to have these covered in my benefits. Consider the same plan than interior health uses.
"ED leadership needs to be re-evaluated if staff turnover is expected to decrease…”

Review pay rates and make them much more comparable to industry standards. Salaries are significantly lower at BC Public Service than in comparable jobs and while I enjoy this organization, if a similar job were to come along with a higher rate of pay, I may seriously consider taking it.
A well defined mission and vision and a clear roadmap to achieve it.   Better communication from the bottom down on strategic initiatives and how to achieve goals on time.
Work life balance
Increased integration between teams/work units within the office to strengthen relationships, improve understanding, and overall improve the EAs we conduct
Provide clear direction on processes and procedures internally and externally so work can be conducted effectively, efficiently and successfully.
"Flatter organization that shares information so everyone can be the best in their job"
Our space is less than ideal with construction and members of our staff do not feel safe in the area at times.
"First and foremost increase pay. I am barely able to make ends meet [in my situation] on the wages paid. They do not adequately meet inflation…"
Better computers!
"Consistency in approach to employees/teams related to opportunities internally and externally…"
EAO could benefit from a more developed employee development program and stronger support from supervisors for employee career development.
"There should be more part-time opportunities for employees. It is very difficult to have career progression if you are only interested in part-time work..."
Continue to consider how EA revitalization and revisions to the EA process can help EAO manage projects and staff workload more effectively.
Meaningful and engaging meetings that are fewer in number, but greater in content and relevance.

Make sure all employees have a functional, comfortable and useable work station when they arrive. Having to wait [a significant amount of time] for all components/equipment to make a functional workspace is not acceptable.
A new physical location designed with a mix of shared collaborative spaces and private offices for sensitive conversations.
"I would work on streamlining our process and policies and the templates we use for reporting…”

"…Managers work a lot of overtime hours and do not receive compensation/hours in lieu. This means that the level lower can actually be compensated higher in some circumstances. I believe this would need to be rectified in order to provide for upward moving opportunities in my organization."
High volume work area where some workers are not as high in productivity needs assessments on how to improve their productivity so the main work load doesn't fall on a few but the whole team

Continue to increase development opportunities to grow our own talent pool in Finance and support their development through special projects or temporary assignments in other ministries or public agencies.
Hire cleaners who will actually clean the building. The current cleaning staff do not do much. The bathrooms are not very clean.

"The only part of the public service I am disappointed with is the wages, employee benefits and pension. I have worked for the public service for [many] years and there have been no raises or minimal raises. Also, I feel we should have better employee benefits (higher limits on dental and extended health and higher pension amounts upon retirement."

We are under staffed. Supervisors push to do more and work harder. Breaks and vacations are seen as a privilege, not a right of enjoyment. People feel guilty for taking them as it puts more work on othres
Make all staff accountable - same rules for all staff

Remove the red tape to allow appropriate office furniture (i.e. office chairs, desks) to be ordered as required to replace the aging furniture currently available in some offices of the ministry of Finance.  How appropriate is it when we have to repair our chairs with duct tape and the only available option to replace them is to look at what is available in surplus - unless you want to write a briefing note to the DM to seek approval to purchase a new chair.
Make sure the work put into succession planning is actually used.

Don't make it so difficult to make a purchase of anything. Why do we need briefing notes to purchase simple items? I work closely with other ministries and to see what their staff are able to purchase without any problems (computers/laptops, desks) compared to what we have in our ministry makes us wonder why we have such a time consuming and difficult process in place. If the purchase is to help someone do their job better or for their physical or mental health, why incorporate delays into the purchase?

Some of our office equipment is in poor condition - broken chairs, dirty dividers.  Would be nice if it would be replaced with better equipment as other branches of our ministry have done - makes a big difference in the workday.
Better communication within the Division!

"I would recommend a better promotional or advancement process internal to current staff. The staff turnover in our organization is frequent and the time it takes for hiring, training and independence is very time consuming for those that continue to remain within the organization."

It is becoming increasingly difficult to attract talent within the salary constraints of our positions. There is a big gap between what we need our employees to do and the salary expectations in the market. We want a lot but are not willing to pay for it, leaving us with either hiring people who don't have the skills we need or leaving positions vacant, putting pressure on those in the unit that have to get the work done.

Hire staff that have the right attitude and personality for the position they will be working in.  Education alone does note make a good employee.  If they are part of a team they need to be a team player, if they are public facing they need to be able to communicate effectively and enjoy that work.  Often times we hire for education and the employee has trouble communicating or matching the brand of the work place.  Focus more on the person and maybe a little less on education.  Creates a much better workplace environment and likely less turnover.
More working together across teams.

… Eliminate the 18/21 productivity benchmark. This objective is causing more harm than good. Managers & TLs are applying this in an inconsistent manner and staff morale & productivity are suffering. Many staff are not able to meet this benchmark in the ordinary course of their work & feel setup to fail. Ultimately this benchmark is creating mistrust of leadership and staff don’t understand the reason behind this standard…

Provide training on the job. 80% of the time my co-workers and myself are thrown into situations where we must be subject matter experts without any training. It makes us feel uneasy and overly stressed. Management and supervisors have no time to sit and train or even explain.

Review the management salaries  because there are inequities and there is no transparency and no way to address.  The application of different salaries for same management positions and duties is unfair.  Equal pay for equal work should be a fundamental principle adhered to by the BCPS  but it is not.  This doesn't  align with being an employer of choice and a great place to work.  It has become very clear that this gap is deliberate with no justification and there is no recourse for those impacted.

"Management team should listen and respect recommendations from general staff. It is common in our organization that recommendations get turn down when the management team feels that the suggestion will not work because the staff are not trust worthy.”

Be more supportive of LWS and a flexible work option. This option should be available to all levels from ED down . To embrace the increased efficiency of cutting down commute time and reduce unnecessary stress. This will also benefit employees' work life balance. Executives should also realize with the evolvement of technology, physical presence is rather not required for most meetings. Having staff's physical presence simply for the sake of socializing does not make any sense, as our job is doing audits, not to socialize with co-workers.
Consistency and fairness especially when running a competition.
Workloads are way too high and most people feel the stress of the said workload. Possibly hire frontline people that could enter returns, answer basic calls, and web messages.
Salaries have not kept pace with increases in the cost of living and housing.  We are falling significantly behind other sectors and regions for the nature of technical expertise required.
"More communication throughout the branch to let staff know what is going on. Instead of hearing 'through the grapevine.”

Cross-training. There needs to be more opportunities for people to stretch themselves and perform work that they don't normally do. (i.e. more temporary assignments, job rotations etc.). This may create more well-rounded and flexible employees which is good for everyone.
Ensure the pay and benefits provided to new employees and current staff is comparable to the pay and benefits in the private sector.

Inclusion.  My direct supervisor has neglected to include, inform or share any relevant work related information with me.  This impacts my job as I am not informed of routine business and I spend time chasing up information that should be afforded to me.  I feel marginalized and excluded and my confidence is being eroded.

Flex days for excluded employees supposedly do not exist in BC Public service. However, excluded employees in some other ministries receive them, just not MoF.  Be fair, let MoF excluded employees have flex days too. It doesn't cost the Government anything extra and goes a long, long....long way towards improving morale thereby resulting in a greatly improved work environment.

Succession planning and promotions/replacement of retiring workers should include budget over the next few years for overlap between outgoing and incoming replacements for key positions. This would make the transitions run much smoother as supervisors, management, and Executives retire.

Competitions have become far too cumbersome for both the hiring agent and job seeker. Technical testing is over-used when it is not relevant for some positions, or the person's designations already clearly show success in the technical area. This over testing is resulting in us no longer hiring the right people or best people, but rather those with testing skills or significant experience with competency based interviews, not always the job or leadership skills we want. We are not always getting the right people, and the whole process has become exhausting and cumbersome for all involved.

Do a better job of cleaning. I find all areas of our building, washrooms and floors to be filthy. I have been in many other government office buildings and they are all clean. I am not sure why ours is not held to the same standard…

There should be a ladies' washroom as close by to the work area as there exists a men's washroom. It is shamefully regressive that women have to go all the way downstairs while men can use the washroom just a short walk away.

I'd like to see more effort to develop internal resources (e.g. mentorship/coaching/training/temporary assignments), particularly to facilitate the jump from included to excluded.  Development and retention are key success factors and I don't think Finance is dedicating enough effort.  For me personally, it was difficult to gain supervisory and leadership experience and so I screened out of many excluded competitions.

With all the discussion around health and wellness I would encourage the employer to be proactive and offer more options around desk setup, including easier access to sit/stand desks. Although there is an initial cost, the investment would pay off in healthy employees in the future

Fairness in pay needs to be simpler administratively to achieve. Though the systems seem to be getting better, there still seems to be large bureaucratic obstacles to ensuring that pay is fair within work units (e.g. that colleagues make the same salary when they do the same job at the same level of performance, or that new staff members aren't hired in at a salary that is higher than their colleagues). It seems like there needs to be easier paths through the administrative red tape in order to make common-sense salary adjustments, which would save a lot of Executive time and energy, and would prevent having to resort to work-arounds like meaningless changes in job title (which can be confusing to colleagues and affect notions of fairness).
Improve the heating (temperature control) and upgrade the facilities (kitchen and washrooms).
Opportunities for job shadowing in areas that line up with career path.

"Level 9 assistants job description be revised for upgrades, it seems that upper levels managements get reclassified in no time. Too often assistants are forgotten and not appreciated for what they do, managements get 'too technical' on why they are not be moved up…”
More training for supervisors  on being effective team leaders.
Encouraging/requiring directors to lead and inspire, rather than stifle innovation and contribute to negativity within the branch.

"I'd appreciate more formal training/learning opportunities (e.g., ability to attend conferences) and informal opportunities (e.g., meet and greets with other areas of Finance to understand their role)…”

Encourage Full time work from home.  Flexible options have become more popular as time goes on, but there is still a biting need to limit this to 50% or less.  I find I work better and more productively at home.  When I have to drive in to work I find I am more stressed out and less productive as the cost and effort of commuting is draining.  My organization would do better to encourage work from home on a full time basis.

I would like to see the government excel in innovation, so that the processes and tools lead to noticeable efficiencies among the staff and the public. Many of the new tools have done the opposite. Staff have been promised efficiencies with new programs; however, when roll out occurs, the programs are often hastily and sloppily published, support for the systems is lacking and they don't meet the needs of the work areas. Government would do better to look to the private sector for innovative ideas and source better contractors.

Wages are not competitive with other public services across the country. BCPSA relies on the 'attractiveness' of Victoria to attract talent, but Victoria's high (and rising) cost of living makes it difficult to thrive on current salary levels.

I believe improvements could be made to the benefits package available for BC GEU members.  I would prefer a more flexible benefits package, where I could choose which benefits money is allocated.  For example, optometry and orthopedics are not benefits that I currently require, so having the ability to allocate the funds available in those specific benefits to a benefit that I do use (massage therapy, drugs, dental, etc.) would be preferred.

Increase the pay to recognize the amount of hours required outside of work to complete the tasks within the timelines and to recognize that providing strategic advice to Treasury Board, the Minister of Finance, and senior Executives on significant financial issues considered by the Province of British Columbia is valuable work

The province should reconsider its selection criteria for leadership roles. Promoting employees from within who have the most factual knowledge as they have been working for the province for the longest time, doesn't necessarily mean that they make great leaders. Often such people tend to continue working as 'working foremen' and lack  skills to lead teams of professionals successfully.

Options to work from home (our department is taking steps to eventually make this a reality but it can't come soon enough)  Flex days! It would be nice to be able to work an extra 45-60mins a day and get every second Friday off for instance.

Changing our physical work environment from closed cubicles to open  spaces - keeping the team together. This creates an environment so employees can speak freely with one another.  Changing desks from one level to better ergonomic height adjustable desks , so to allow employees to move their body around freely and reduce body stress and exhaustion.   Change lighting to softer light. Change enclosed environment to include windows that can be open for fresh air; minimize recirculated air.  Allow staff to have the ability to work outside on nice days.  Include a relaxed common break room.
Being able to work remotely would be nice, especially since my work does not require me to be physically present in a specific place.

Invest the time in staff to understand their career aspirations and what motivates them.  Thoughtfully consider how to create the development opportunities to enable your staff to incrementally achieve their goals. On their career path they need space to stretch themselves and grow, to make mistakes and learn valuable lessons, and through it all, as leaders it is your responsibility to be their safety net and mentor.  People are your most valuable asset.  Invest the time upfront to coach, support and develop staff, and the rewards will be ten-fold.

Increase flexible work options for those who have a long commute. Often I hear of people with up to 12 hour days when travel time is included, and utilizing technology to help reduce distance people need to travel to get to work would likely improve productivity and engagement.

"I find my immediate supervisor not very approachable when I have questions, or comments. My other coworkers are very helpful. I haven't been with the government for very long but I do wish I could feel comfortable to ask for help when needed and I don't feel that way with everyone."
Have all the MMHA staff located in one area in the building, and have appropriate space/offices for everyone.

Staff are exhausted by the lack of clarity on structure ,and the frequent changes in staffing, alignment and division/branch mandate. It would be helpful to have the structure confirmed so that staff can start to work toward their work unit's objectives.
"Finalize and clarify strategic plan…"
"Continue focusing on organizational development…"
I would like my organization to focus on modern communication tools, online and offline, and making sure people have the physical tools to get the work done.

While I understand that my organization is currently focussed on solving the terrible physical situation, the longer this difficult situation continues, the more it becomes disrespectful of the people and the work we do.  The expectations of our staff are very high and this terrible space situation is not commensurate with those expectations.

Provide us with the tools, resources and space to do our jobs effectively. This includes co-locating all ministry staff in a space that supports our mental wellness (e.g., natural light) and nurtures relationship building.
Communication, and clear direction that is followed through would be very helpful.
As our ministry works to identify its strategic vision/mission I hope that they follow through with their commitment to do 'things differently'.
"…There is little communication from Executive as to when we can expect to move to a more appropriate location..."
"Communicating with staff - no consideration for how lack of clarity affects our everyday work..."

"A one stop place where we can go to review and Executive/reporting team can communicate on the current strategies and upcoming strategies so staff that aren't immediately involved with this information can stay up-to-date. A sort of newsflash, point-form messaging - even on the MMHA intranet…"
"Better communication of decisions that impact my work."
The Executive should engage and listen to the staff. It feels good when you have been heard, it feels bad when you are ignored.

"Acknowledgement of work load and efforts to address the real fall out from Axiom. "
