Work processes are taking 5 times the time it took before and there is no indication that things will improve in the very near term. Staff are extremely frustrated and there is little assurance that can be provided given the system has been in place for nearly 10 months. Morale is quite low and stress levels are high."

The CEO needs to be more visible, there are people in this building who do not know what she looks like. The CEO must be more sensitive to the frustration of staff members, who are passionate about their jobs and want to provide the highest level of service, but cannot do so due to the persisting challenges of the new computer system…
"Focus on fixing core/base problems with new Trust accounting system rather than inefficient work-around processes."
Address workload demands and staff retention.
"Not enough work space for employees (too close for comforts); not even a storage unit for employees' files/personal belongings.  Photocopier/scanner/printer are too old & frequently breaking-down."
"More 'meat and potatoes' training on the newly implemented system rather than just overview. Different options for learning rather than just online videos. Closed captioning for online learning."

Our workloads have always been heavy. However with the implementation of a new financial system in our organization last year, our workloads have become unmanageable. This new system was supposed to improve things but the process has in turn become more time consuming as it adds extra steps to every task, which adds pressure to our workloads…

"We implemented a new accounting system which has completely changed the way I do my job.  I no longer have control over my work and how I do it.  Everything takes much longer.  I no longer provide quality service, but correct system errors, field complaints and make excuses for why things take so long. It has increased all of our workloads.  It has changed the general mood of the office; much more stress all round and quick to blame others for errors.  People are taking shortcuts to get things done and making mistakes.  The public is losing patience with our office.  There does not seem to be real understanding by exec. I feel like I'm on the Titanic and no one wants to admit that we hit the iceberg."
"Better training for positions, procedures updated and loaded to reference library and kept updated. Training done on  a person to person basis."

I recommend a substantial investment in the Axiom system (Client Financial Trust Accounting system) and its reporting capabilities. Further investments in Document Management are also urgently needed.
"Work shadowing in different division.  Give opportunity to staff to work in other division temporary to get a feel of job interest."
I would like to see the implementation of a new phone system in order to better serve our clients, stakeholders, the public and employees. The current system is too archaic.

"Implement computer programs (Case Management and Trust Accounting Programs) that are intuitive, effective and efficient. The programs in current use require excessive duplication of data, time-consuming searches for information, and convoluted, complex  directions for performing the simplest of tasks. These programs are the biggest impediment we face to providing timely and efficient service to the public."
"Pay - extreme discrepancies between excluded and included staff and those between other crown corporations and other levels of govt."

"Effective change management that is sincerely responsive in a timely manner to feedback for improvement. Actions speak louder than words. Employees do not feel valued if it appears their concerns are not taken seriously. We lose very valuable employees due to unacceptable working conditions - this is unacceptable and should be avoided at all costs."
"More staff if AX is here to stay."
"Improving axiom."

"We are not compensated fairly for the work that we do. Employees feel that we are not valued and respected for the work that we do. Our skills are transferable to other jobs and organizations who will compensate us fairly. Higher pay would make employees more likely to remain at the PGT long term and feel appreciated for the work they do."

"I love my job, however, I do a lot more than is required for my pay grade.  I would feel more valued, and stay at my current position, if the pay grade could be increased.  Time to revisit pay grades."

"I feel like the biggest issue facing the public service is increasing workload and stress without increased pay and benefits. The pay gap between private and public means we are losing good people, not because they want to leave, but because they can't afford to live in [city] with current public service pay. Increases in stress and workload, if not offset by pay increases will mean more people continue to leave.  My suggestion for improvement: Find a way to either reduce stress and workload or to increase pay grades."

"I think more focus on career development would be beneficial to all staff. Even though, BCPSA offers programs such as the Pacific Leaders Program to encourage employees to push beyond their work boundaries and strive for more, the budget for this program within the organization is very limited to a point that is discouraging.  More funding for courses through LMS from PGT as well as more courses open to all employees through the Learning Centre would be ideal as employees want to build their knowledge. "
"Improve work environment by investing in upgrades to work stations and kitchen areas in the building."
"We need more staff.  Everything is so much harder now.  Its all just way too much.  We don't have the support we need"

"Information should be freely shared between the Executive members and front-line staff.  There should be clearer and more direct lines of communication, so that front line staff, who are often more versed and able to recognize the issues in their work unit (and ultimately the organization) can express their thoughts and feelings.  Otherwise, front line staff feels like they have to wallow in the things which are not going well and no one is listening to their concerns."

"Staff are overworked and stressed due to staffing shortages. There are not enough employees for the amount of work that needs to be done. Positions have been eliminated and staff are required to take on additional responsibilities without an increase in their pay."

"Every employee should be ergonomically assessed at their work stations especially when they move to a different work station. Everyday essentials should be provided (i.e., tissues and filtered water)."

"I'd appreciate more information about job opportunities in other divisions - either on a formal or informal basis. The job descriptions don't provide a good picture of what the day-to-day work involves. It's hard to determine if I'd be considered as a candidate. I'd also like to know more about training opportunities and courses that would benefit me in my current role or when it comes to applying for roles in other departments. What courses are eligible for funding? What courses did other employees attend/find useful?"
"Salaries need to be increased for this workplace to remain a competitive option for employees."
Provide strong and positive leadership in order to correct the lack of trust between managers and line staff. Some staff do not even know who the managers are and vice versa.
Promotions be based on merit, experience and knowledge. Promoting people who have none of these makes for a toxic workplace and builds resentment.

"Review advancement requirements & standards; those that talk well are promoted but actual experience isn't valued. We used to be promoted on seniority and the pendulum has swung too far the other way; no experience but good with [talking]."
The one thing that I would like is when an employee retires that a new person would be hired instead of passing the work onto already overworked employees.
Workload has become so high that it is unmanageable at times.
We don't get paid enough for the dangerous work we do.  We work in close proximity with angry, abusive & unpredictable inmates everyday without the appropriate compensation.

Wages/benefits are not keeping up with cost of living. Corrections work is now becoming a 'secondary income' type of job. Not a family supporting job. I would like to stay but it becomes a bottom line money decision.

Pay and compensation is the elephant in the room.  Compared with other large provinces, federal and municipal governments the pay and compensation  is severely lacking.  How does the BCPS expect to attract and retain talent?

More focus on learning and development and assisting staff to achieving their long term career goals.   Part of that is about more relevant courses and part of that is about giving people time to take those courses.   Government should also focus on supporting personal long term career growth.
Staff retention. Being a long term member of the BCPS I am having a hard time training new people over and over again

Staff require strict legislation to protect them from the daily assaults by inmates that have limited to no consequences for their actions. It is up to my 'organization' to act as liason for staff and push Victoria for protection via legislation. The organization has to be less self serving and care about the safety of their staff.
I would like all staff to be treated in a fair and respectful manner, free from discrimination.

I would like to see a change in the hiring process.  For years I have seen how this has not worked.  It appears that managers have their eye on an employee that either they see as a good fit and or like and then they start to groom them  This shows other staff that favoritism was involved and it sets the tone of unfairness. Also to have senior staff from another centre sit in on the panel.

My direct supervisor is very busy and often unavailable for long periods of time.  When I have things I need to discuss, or would like to discuss this can be very challenging and sometimes results in me making the decision on my own without the benefit of my supervisors input.

Provide opportunities for career advancement and growth, including opportunities to take on new challenges, chair meetings, brief up to Executives, make presentations, lead projects and anything that will contribute to a learning opportunity.

"Staffing has been reduced. Backfill hours have not been increased and it’s impossible to take professional development opportunities without resorting to other staff from my unit to cover my work causing workload stress."

make hiring and promotion better by removing barriers. For example, behavioural events interviews are terrible. Find better ways to screen and find good candidates who have the right skills and aptitude for the chosen job

"Start seriously planning for succession [and] retention is becoming laughable at best. For what we spend on recruiting it should be invested into better wages to maintain long term retention and thereby growth of employees."

I'd like to be able to go to my supervisor and be inspired and encouraged and not constantly feel like I am interrupting when I have questions and/or concerns regarding my work. Overall supervision and guidance of new staff needs improvement. I have observed that management in our office is inexperienced and/or just care about their job duties and not their staff.

Eliminating favoritism in promotional panels and make the process completely impartial ( No one that sits on the panel should have any vested interest in the outcome and not report to anyone with any interest in the outcome )

Improve on benefits for chiropractor, physio, eyeglasses, etc.  For example, every chiro visit, coverage is only $8 which is a very small portion and results in not getting the treatment required because of the cost.  When your eyeglass lenses alone are over $450 plus frames on top of that, another high cost.

Facilities - Many of our offices are outgrowing their infrastructure and improvements/renovations are needed to create and improve working space for staff. The budget is very limited and the process for obtaining facilities funding is very challenging and frustrating. There simply isn't enough to meet our growing needs and this is a point of contention for staff and managers alike.

A pay increase to reflect the current cost of living within BC and one that is competitive to other law enforcement agencies would help with job retention… A pay increase that would motivate staff to remain in their careers would also benefit staff's work/life balance improving the quality of service.
Staff retention. We tend to get people from the coast who just come here and get their training and then move on. It would be nice to hire someone local who has no plans of leaving.

What I can think of right now is about succession planning. A very challenging situation with the rate of our senior staff and management retiring, there is a strong need to increase the development of new leaders within our organizations and with a fair hiring process for those employees where development and training has been invested. Could be favorable to get extra FTEs to support the operations so experienced and capable employees can invest time job shadowing senior employees to get prepared to assume these roles as they become available, but also with good management strategies to retain them.
There is a big need for improvement in the level of respect we get from the management. We deserve much more respect.
Pay and Benefits.  Spouses who work for the BC public Service don't get their medical benefits covered off by one another.

management to staff communication is very poor.  There is also a near complete lack of management trying to know their staff.  In my opinion a good manager knows the staff, and the strengths and weakness of those staff.  The manager then works with the staff to capitalize on the strengths and work on the weaknesses.

… There seems to be an allowance by the organization to continue to pile more expectations & policy constraints on individual frontline workers without offsetting their other obligations & failing to create additional job positions to help alleviate this demand. I strongly feel that I could do my job much better, more efficiently, and with more meaning if the workload was just more manageable…
Hire people who really care about their employees versus their own agendas for pay increases… Just because people are good at following rules and regulations does not mean they are inspiring leaders.
Pay and benefits continue to be a major issue each year.  Overall satisfaction in working for the BC Public Service is not going to improve until employees feel they are paid fairly.
"It is my belief that in the correctional environment there is a developing crisis of inmate rights directly compromising officer safety."

"Too many things are needed. Bullying, disrespect, dominance, and inappropriate behaviour is a form of communication in this workplace coming straight from the management team. That needs to change to ensure a non-toxic work environment. 'Favorites' is not tolerated in the workplace as well. This 'employees versus management' atmosphere needs to change in the workplace..."

Communicate more with employees. Support your employees, in our organisation it seems that the managers and supervisors are just looking for mistakes people make not asking for ideas or listening. It is more of a do it my way or no way thought process with little support from managers.

"Pay is not up to the standards and expectations in our economy. Most of my fellow employees need to have multiple jobs just to pay their bills. For myself personally, my pay is not equal to others in the same profession. It is actually around 30% lower. Very difficult to stay motivated when others in society are reaping the rewards of their employers while I feel like I am wasting my life away by being loyal to the public service..."
Staff are left in the dark when it comes to injuries/assaults occurring at the work place.  Management does not talk about it; therefore staff feel unvalued and unimportant.
I would suggest a mentoring program (or work shadow) to learn other tools that could be used in this unit

My work environment badly needs a facilities upgrade, the physical standards of the building do not align with the principles set out in Where Ideas Work.  Simple things like computer software and hardware limit my productivity unnecessarily.

We need safer solutions for our unit officers. Our current living unit model is no longer suitable due to the high number of inmates we are faced with on a daily basis. The government also HAS to recognize that the level of risk vs the financial reward are horribly inadequate which will always result in poor job satisfaction, and high turnover rates. You need to compensate people who are risking their lives for the sake of the public, and the public service.
I would like transparency, integrity and honesty from some of the managers to be at our forefront as I feel that this aspect is lacking.
Hold people accountable for their actions - it seems as though when things happen no one is held accountable.

"Workplace needs more staff members. One officer on a unit with 30-60 inmates is not enough, which shows. Over the last several years multiple officers have been assaulted, some very severely. When officers are in direct contact with inmates, they should have a second officer as back up…”

Review of the buildings our offices are in, as there are concerns about health issues. Most of the people in our office are sneezing and stuffed up within a few minutes of being in the building. People have come in to check things before, but the issues are not resolved.

Fixing the issues with the computer systems and programs that we use daily. Without their proper function(s) virtually our entire department comes to an almost complete stand still until the issues are resolved.

There is not enough administrative staff to meet the needs of such a large office.  There is too much work to be done with the limited staff we have and the work is not always able to get done.  More staff needs to be hired to meet the demand.

I believe that my organization should focus on less projects/initiatives. We are trying to work 100 miles an hour towards a bunch of different projects. We should pick a choice few, complete them, and then work on others. Further, we are consistently being mandated with new programs to fulfill legislative needs and as far as I am aware we are not receiving more employees do what is required. The result is employees receiving more tasks with an already high workload.
Safer work environment - single staffed living units with upwards of 60 inmates is extremely unsafe which results in staff assaults.
Getting outside the office for fresh air and exercise. Making this a priority.

Corrections… isn't a bad place to work for personally, but when it comes to the divide between management and staff, it’s a big reason why people leave. Management hardly knows how a unit is run but tries to crack down and discipline the officers without looking at the big picture which is the inmates and the things we deal with as staff…

I would like to focus on safety - such as proper heating and ergonomics. I believe everyone who works at a desk should have the option to utilize a stand up desk as it prevents injury in the long term.
Have more team building activities for staff.
sensitivity training for everyone to help self identify how 'tone' can be perceived

I would like to see more opportunities for growth within the BC Public Service, especially for people living in smaller rural communities. It would be nice to not have to move to a larger city to obtain job growth.

The cost of living in the lower mainland continues to rise and I believe the wage does not correlate with the basic needs of an individual trying to live in BC. As someone that enjoys their role within the public service my heart often does weigh over the logical side of me stating that it is unmanageable to continue working just one job within the public service. As a university educated individual who does find gratification in my job, it is often hard to balance the idealistic side that if the pay and benefits do not reflect our current needs. I know the public service does state and highlight the stress of a healthy work life balance; but, needing a second job is becoming more of a reality, it is truly disappointing and disheartening.

Morale. There is a lot of great work that can be done but the energy is often very low. There are a lot of critical people who don't seem keen to offer empathy and compassion to the public who we are meant to be serving.
To bring the staff together rather than everyone working against eachother.  Telling, gossip behind one another backs.  Makes for a negative atmosphere.  That's the hardest part I feel for me.

Make issues affecting staff wellness and providing enabling tools/technologies a priority. Budget priorities are too heavily focused on service delivery at the expense of the supporting improved office and working environments.
Allow for money to be spent on training for auxiliary employees to enhance ones opportunity for training and advancement.

Clean up computer clutter such as wires, etc. (ensure workspaces are tangle free)…  Update [software]… Provide equipment to staff including flashlights, hoods for rain jackets, belt inserts and other useful items other law enforcement agencies provide their staff…

The biggest improvement that could be made to my work unit is to completely overhaul the training. Currently, training is provided while staff members are already managing a full workload. If staff members were given the ability to focus on training prior to starting their workload, they would have more confidence, pride, and be more efficient in their job.
Clearer paths for advancement, I feel stuck in my job with no logical next step to move up.  I feel I will have to leave my organization for another ministry to progress in my career
More on the job training to familiarize ourselves with potential situations that could arise.

"Reduce the major importance of the competency interviews when it comes to selecting candidates for new job positions.  I find that throughout the organization individuals are not chosen by merit and or experience but by who they know and how well they can embellish themselves.  This is a common complaint throughout the province for those who are not in the practice boasting about themselves what they have done in the past.   In practice, we are encouraged to act as a team and to be truthful.  We are to use 'We' instead of 'I' but when it comes to the interview process for a new position we must embellish our past experience which to some individuals is hard to do... "
Ensure Executives and managers have extensive experience in their line of work. Working for people who do not understand the job is very difficult…

"Changing the name of my organization to remove specific programs out of the title as there are several programs that are not identified.  I don't think we should have all the programs listed but a composite of the work we focus on.  When I tell people who I work for (the full and proper name), people think it is a joke."

"Technology and the correct tools to perform our jobs in an efficient manner. Our technology, software and network connections are so old they are in some cases not even supported anymore. We should be industry leaders in innovative use of technology, not 10 years behind others."

Clear and constant updates on priorities. Priorities for the land base, priorities for spending, priorities for engagement, priorities for communication.  People are being spread too thin and without clear guidance, they gravitate to their preference which may or may not be aligned with government's current priorities.

"Improve the coordination of business prioritisation and planning between business units to build a proper sense of mutual support and during the process, increase the pace of decision making on pressing issues, particularly in reconciling competing priorities and demands on capacity."

"My organization needs to engage in two way communication and be more engaging with staff. Many decisions are made without operational input and staff feel managers are not making good decisions about organizational direction. There is no trust between operational staff and the managers."

"The range of branches and programs within FLNRO is huge creating an extremely complex Ministry. I believe that reducing the spectrum of programs (and size of the Ministry) would assist in making the Ministry function more effectively and would focus the vision/mission."

I am significantly concerned over the apparent lack of support for rural communities/field units in favor of centralizing in larger centers. I would like to see a return of support to the rural area's/field units in terms of resourcing specifically staffing.

"Benefits are limited in terms of what I need. I pay a lot out of pocket for prescriptions. Physio and massage benefits are quite limited. Counselling is extremely limited... In terms of extended health, we would be much better off if one of us worked for the Federal government or a private organization..."

"Invest in building upgrades that provide for a healthier work place. (My work place has been using the same cubicle dividers for over 35 years. The carpet has been replaced once in the last 35 years)."
"Personal Accountability - when people are just not doing their core job functions then make them aware and have personalized goals for those individuals."
"Sort out restrictions & approval process for furniture/chair replacement process. An increase in staff requires new desks, chairs etc, and the breakage of existing equipment."

There's lack of knowledge transfer process.  Experienced staff are retiring without adequate training and knowledge transfer to the incoming new staff.  We must have one to two years overlap at the technical skills level to effectively hand over the torch.
"Human Resources: reducing staff turnover, filling positions quickly, resourcing appropriately to meet demand."

"...I hear people are overloaded with work, however I also hear that they continue to work on things that are no longer a priority, just what they like to do. Managers need to focus their attention on employees and help ensure they are focused on the right things."
"By promoting and following a clear and transparent reclassification process."

"My direct supervisor and Manager need to communicate changes more effectively and often.  There is no open door policy. We often have to book appointments to discuss work related topics, these appointments are often changed without notice.  There is a definite lack of continuity, messaging, approaches to problem solving and the changes and reasons for the changes are not being messaged to the staff that are impacted.  Messaging and clarity are required and the supervisory staff must make themselves available."

"Start a mentoring program immediately before the Gen X and Baby boomers are all gone. These groups are leaving the service in hoards and the values, service orientation, common knowledge and bush skills are being lost and degraded by the lack of crossover with the 'grey hairs'. Knowledge of the history goes with the retirees and I fear for the future of the province with the short sightedness that seems to be happening. New employees don't have the skills and experience and aren't getting them fully because there is no one to learn from now in many departments. Leaning from books or industry is not adequate."
"A faster posting and hiring process for filling staff positions."

"Clearly articulating the vision and goals and provide the resourcing to meet those goals that is equitable between branches, regions and departments (most importantly between regions) and equitable between economic and sustainability focused departments."
"Spend more time mentoring new supervisors.  Some new supervisors are not aware of the best ways to supervise staff."

"Training and/or instruction manuals for new computer equipment is virtually non- existent. IE : Forest Techs use IPADS with mapping capabilities on them, and when given this equipment do not receive any training on how they are to be used...It would be useful when giving people this newer technology, some guidance on how to use the technology."
"Review current workload and eliminate unnecessary work or procedures. Current workload is not sustainable."

"Succession and retention strategies to retain and utilize key [work unit]auxiliaries.. Examine making them full time regular employees, which will assist with succession planning and retention, and the workload."
"Career paths in specialty areas is limited, we need to pay attention to how we can improve on this."
"Underpaid for the work we are responsible to deliver."
"Low staffing levels continue to be a threat to job satisfaction and contribute to employee stress. Ensure staff resources are included before taking on any new initiative"
"Less limitations on computer  hardware and software. We are trying to be innovative but are constantly hindered by slow computers, not enough drive space etc."

The administrative burden associated with contract administration is overwhelming. The current system focuses more on having all the check lists and forms completed than on efficiency or effectiveness. One form in particular, [form number] is a multi-page monster… There is a serious need to re-do the lean process that produced this abomination and come up with a short form for common and simple contracts...
Continue to promote leadership training and development for all staff at all levels, not just managers. (eg Leader in You, LEAD, AETP, Co-Op program, Temp. Assignments).

The organization, Senior staff, and public work load expectations are continuing to increase. Daily, monthly, annually, new processes and job requirements are added. This work increase does not come with a prioritization of what is lowest and can drop. This ever-increasing expectation (Exponential) creates enormous stress on staff in our work place.

Streamline decision making at all levels. Consider an alternative to the working group model to streamline decision making. Ensure feedback mechanisms are in place and functioning to avoid organizational silos when implementing decisions. The organization is dynamic and we need to be able to react to issues efficiently when needed.
"Add capacity in the form of FTE, both included and excluded. Despite workload prioritization, projects and core work aren't getting completed."
Better equity on job classification.  Newly created jobs are classified higher than established jobs while having less accountabilities, requirements (professional and education).

"Align expectations with resources. Expectations to deliver are through the roof (land use planning, First Nations reconciliation, wildfire recovery, increased complexity of managing lands and resources, social license, etc.). We don't have the people we need to deliver. Stress is extremely high throughout the organization. We need to start saying no to some things, or have the resources we need to deliver. I am seeing staff burning out, starting to look for other employment, etc. I think we're near a tipping point and I'm extremely concerned, for myself, but also for my staff."

I would like my organization to focus on increasing salaries for people in remote areas, for specialists, hard to fill positions, and for positions that are located in expensive areas (e.g. Vancouver, Victoria), for financial support. At least to the federal government standards. This will probably never change, but it should be looked at and fixed. We lose some excellent people due to the attraction of higher salaries and benefits to the federal government because of this.

"Improve options for reducing noise in the workplace, e.g. noise cancelling headphones, laptops to take calls/lync meetings in small meeting rooms, more small meeting rooms, increased communication to staff of reducing noise in the office."

"Increase in budget - this would allow us to have AGMs as well as more training opportunities. Because we can't afford this, it results in inconsistency across the province, a decrease in good teamwork, less communication, etc."

"I would like to see more defined application and referral processes established to support our projects.  Also, with most of our team working remotely I think it would be beneficial to explore a digital filing system."
"Change value for capital purchases from $1,000 to $2,000."
"Ensure all work units are coordinated and working towards the same goals and priorities."

"Budget restraints are inconsistent between work units as well as Divisions/Departments within the organization. One unit needs to negotiate to purchase small items while other Divisions/Departments are given additional year end funding for improvements and training. This can result in a department/unit feeling less valued. I fully support saving money for the Province as long as it is done equitably."
"Ensure staff are doing their jobs; holding others accountable. Hire supervisors who actually like supervising people (and care about them!)"
"Salaries/Benefits/ and Compensation should be reviewed to reflect the labour market."
"Stronger channels of communication with the individual who directly supervises my work and more feedback and guidance would make me much happier in my current position and work unit."

"Older phones and lack of modern media devices set us back in working with clients. Need to modernize to keep up with increasing workload and limited capacity within organization. Increased pressure on staff to excel requires tools to do job effectively."

"Paid sick days at 100%. It is the norm with other employers to have a certain number of fully paid sick days. In an otherwise good organization, I feel undervalued when forced to choose between going to work sick and losing out in pay."

"... Better flooring than old carpet that holds dirt and off-gasses. In fact, working in buildings with quality air and light control is a big part of wellness. Maybe as a government we can better leverage our influence to have the landlords we rent from update their spaces."

"Make Ergonomic desk options more available for every employee to serve as a preventative and proactive measure rather than a reactive measure. It shouldn't be treated as a last resort and should be easier for employees to obtain. Sitting is not healthy even for people that don't have health issues - shouldn't need previous health issue to qualify."

Professional training is nominal, particularly in child protection.  Workers realize that only basic competency is required to satisfy the organizational requirements.  Professional development and other training opportunities should be provided to foster a 'professional' workplace culture.
Please provide more adequate staffing in order to give our vulnerable youth the proper care they so desperately need

Communication and sharing of information from management/supervisors is poor . There's a definite hierarchy and folks that get supervisory positions often don't have the training or the personality to be good leaders.
Our entire work unit is underpaid for the work they do.  This affects the ability to retain qualified staff and results in spending a significant amount of time recruiting and training new staff.

More staff are needed to be able to do the job well. Our team is short-staffed. Many of my answers relate to this. I love what I do but am stressed because we are expected to keep doing our jobs well without enough people on our team! It is unfair to expect this and have pressure to get everything done on the front-line in child protection. Hire more staff please, this is a crisis and staff stress increases when it is not dealt with.

"It is very difficult to attend supervisor training. There is a very long wait list and it is only offered perhaps once or twice a year. It is outrageous, in my opinion that supervisors have to wait years to attend two day training."

Allow all employees to try temporary assignments as opportunities to learn new skills and contribute in new ways.  Allow all employees equal opportunity training, to team days, and to professional development.

"I live in one of the most expensive cities in the world and my pay does not reflect this at all. Our wages have not kept up with inflation and we all struggle more and more each year to have a decent standard of living. People doing the same professional job as me, across Canada, make more money than me. It is outrageous!!!! I work in a high stress and complex job - we are not treated with respect when we are not fairly compensated. ICBC rates get hiked and all sorts of expenses go up and up and we basically get a pay cut year after year. It is unfair and insulting."

"Update the computer/lap top I need to do my job quickly and efficiently. At times entire days are wasted due to the equipment I have been given to use. Lap tops are outdated, freeze, and lose entire documents. Very frustrating."
I would like to see a review of pay and benefits for excluded managers that would lead to salaries reflective of the work that we do.  We are sorely  underpaid.
"Team leaders and supervisors require more clinical and supervisory training to be more effective team managers. This training should occur before assuming the position of team leader."
A less open-plan workplace. There's a lot of socializing in my office which makes it difficult to focus some days.

For the work we do with the most vulnerable children and families of this province we are not provided with adequate pay. Counterparts in other provinces such as Alberta make [significantly more]. Working more specifically for MCFD the burn out rate is high and the work is stressful. More focus needs to be on improving the benefits for services that provide self-care to employees.
Conduct 360 reviews on direct supervisors and act on the findings.

I would like to see improvement in pay and benefits equal to that of teachers and nurses. We work as hard as they do and have equal or more stressors. Seems unfair that they get better pay and better benefits.

We are in a new building that has many wonderful features, but it also has many limitations that make work more challenging than before. This includes lights that cause eye issues, cold room temperature that cannot be controlled, and an overall significant increase in noise levels.

It would be beneficial for long term employees to feel that their are different employment  options available for them. It feels limiting in that way. I would like to try a different position within the organizatin however it does not seem available as there are not many positions.

Staffing.  MCFD is chronically understaffed.  Our caseloads are almost unmanageable, and the stress of not being on top of the work leads to burnout.  Child Protection Workers do not receive the recognition they deserve for the incredibly draining, stressful work they do.

The benefits received are far below that provided to other employees with similar responsibilities but with different employers (the health authority for example).  This makes it difficult to remain in the Public Service as I age and need more extended benefits such as health benefits.  If a comparable position came up, I would consider leaving the Public Service for that reason alone.
"I think it would be appropriate for all staff to be able to request a 'stand-up' desk without having to prove it medically necessary."
"I don't feel supported by my team leader or manager. When I go above and beyond there is no recognition. Things are unstable at work and I am not supported by the management in the changes."

More admin staff would allow more support to workers for tasks that can be done by that team, which would reduce workload burden in general and potentially provide the opportunity for staff to excel rather than merely do their jobs adequately
The expectation/culture that huge caseloads and unmanageable workloads are normal and part of the job needs to change.

"Workspace environment: it's crowded, we work in pods; it is very noisy, which is so distracting for phone calls and written work. The lighting is fluorescent, which produces headaches and sore eyes for many staff members. The office temperature is freezing cold, and we are expected to purchase specific heaters [which are costly] if we want to heat up our pod space. People wear coats and blankets at their desks. The air quality is poor and people in the office are chronically ill. It would be good if we could use our laptops and work from home more often, [as] that would alleviate some of the workplace distractions."

"…Increase workers to reduce caseload numbers. This would increase the quality of services that we can provide to children and families in BC. Ultimately this would reduce the number of children in care through support to families and through more efficiency in finding forever families for children that are in permanent care..."

The physical work environment does not make me feel valued as an employee working for the BC Govt. There is not enough room for the level of staffing in the work unit, with limited rooms/access to rooms to run effective services. The actual physical space does not meet the needs of clients in that it is not confidential, looks run down (despite the best efforts of staff to improve), and is embarrassing to bring community members into. The physical space is uncomfortable to work in (heat/cold), and I am sure is not earthquake or fire proof. These difficulties have led to a decrease in team morale. Concerns from staff need to be taken seriously and addressed in a timely manner.

As social workers/team leaders we are over worked and are facing greater challenges working with complex situations.  We are asked to do more and more work with little resources and a shortage of staffing.  Efforts have been made to recruit and retain staff. However, this continues to be a huge need.  Workers who have been around for years are getting burnt out due to work load demands.  This area needs to improve.

I think that we do amazing work and that there are so many social workers who work really hard and genuinely care for the families. I don't think that our salary is comparable to the work we do. We are put in dangerous situations that are high risk; have heavy caseloads; and multi task every day. I think we should get paid more along the lines of child protection workers in other provinces as we are the lowest paid in Canada.

Given the age and wear and tear of our work space, we need some new furniture and/or repair, cleaning, etc.   This isn't normally what I focus on but our workspace is used by several hundred clients and families a year and has not been looked after properly for many years.

I feel like there are far too many issues surrounding computer slowness and crashes. This creates massive workflow concerns and inefficiencies , as well as frustrating staff. Often the computers (or applications) are unable to keep up with how fast staff are able to work, making it hard to meet deadlines.

"Being a front line worker it is frustrating having to deal with management and consultants who have been removed from the daily struggles, chaos and crisis that front line workers deal with on a daily basis. This is what creates the stress not the clients, when you are looking for support or answers or trying to find placements for the many children in our province and no one is there. It feels like MCFD is a business more about money then about taking care of the vulnerable children and families in BC. It would be nice to have management recognize who their staff are, what they are about, and what skills and education they have.  I don't think they even know who I am."

My organization needs to have more and better opportunities for meaningful staff training and skill development… There should be an expectation that the organization works to contribute to ongoing professional development in a more meaningful way.

"Too often teams are isolated, and do not know what other teams do or what programs or contracts they have access too. More information between teams needs to be shared. Of course more access to resources or abilities to build natural community connections would be nice in order to support our day to day work as well."

"I would love to see more employees accountable for their mistakes. I've never worked in an environment like this, where the employee is not held responsible for their own actions. We get group emails with a broad description of the issue. Nothing ever said to the actual employee who made the mistake. This lack of accountability really gets me upset. I do my job well and to see others cut corners daily and get away with it, seems to be acceptable here and is infuriating...."

"The workload issues need to be addressed. The volume of families per worker and the complexity of the cases are growing. In addition to the amount of paper work and documentation the current work loads are unmanageable. This leads to very high stress level which impacts not only our work but our home lives. The trend of more and more workers needed to take STIIP leaves speaks to a very unhealthy workplace and this needs to be addressed. How can workers feel successful and happy in their jobs when every day we are buried with unending list of to do's? This constant demand and stress of never being able to fully mange and be on top of everything wears on you and creates a very unhealthy work environment."

"I believe there is little accountability for supervisors. The system does not make it easy to complain about supervisor behaviour to their supervisor as you have to go through the person being complained about. This is a serious flaw. There is also no standardized way for front line workers to confidentiality evaluate the performance of their direct supervisors."
I wish the benefits package for health care, dental and drugs is much more comprehensive, with less or no dectubiles.

I feel our benefits package through our extended medical is severely inadequate for the work that we do.  From a front line admin to front line social worker the need for an excellent benefits package is crucial to supporting the work we are faced with and the current package does not support the mental health and well-being of the workers in this ministry.

Staffing shortages in the North.   My caseload is incredibly unmanageable due to staffing, and I feel like I cannot serve the families I work with to the best of my ability as a result. I have also started to burn out, and have distanced myself from my own loved ones because I am so exhausted during my spare time.

"I would like social workers to be involved and consulted when it comes to changes in the work environment. The role of front line child welfare workers is emotionally demanding and extremely difficult. Recent changes have significantly reduced and limited actual work space, have compromised the ability talk in confidence, increased noise/distraction levels and put workers in a position needing to consistently move around in order to complete work. This takes away from being able to stay focussed and be the most productive. Please support what workers need who are on the front line, use our input. Our most vulnerable families depend on SW's to be at their best to ensure the safety of their children."
There needs to be better training for new hires. There is too much of a gap when new hires start to when they actually start their training.

"Better work space and environment. We have rats and mice in our office that we see daily, and it’s not a safe workplace in this aspect at all and it effects how well we are able to do our jobs that we take very seriously."

"I would like my organization to focus on our pay. We are burned out and struggling to pay for our bills which makes the work even harder. [We] are not able to fully support ourselves while having to do this work. I love working with families and children however it is not sustainable for the long term. I urge you to review our wages and bring them up to par with other provinces. Our pay is not up to par with the living standards in BC. I don't want to leave this job because I feel it is meaningful work, however the pay makes it unrealistic. This why we aren't able to retain social workers. I don't understand how you expect to retain workers with this low pay. Please help us!!"
Provide all necessary training before expecting a new employee to take on a full case load.

As a new employee, I feel there would be great benefit in training and orientation. My experience thus far has been a lot of figuring things out on my own (computer systems, protocol, office procedure, HR and benefits, etc.). While my team and supervisor have been supportive and willing to assist in any way possible, I am conscious of just how busy my work environment can be, and don't always want to bother people with questions. Orientation and training specific to job duties/role would help to make new employees much more efficient, confident, and competent in their position, and therefore stronger members of the team. This would help a new employee feel more capable in their role, and would also help them transition and settle in.

It is challenging to be on Auxiliary appointments for lengthy periods of time (and even promoted to higher level Acting positions) without permanency. It would be nice if there was more transparency around the Auxiliary appointment process and the ability of positions to become permanent.
